name: Star Trek Online
description: In Star Trek Online, the Star Trek universe appears for the first time on a truly massive scale. Players take the captain's chair as they command their own starship and crew. Explore strange new worlds, seek out new life and new civilizations, and boldly go where no one has gone before.
minimum_requirements: Minimum OS: Windows® Vista, 7, 8 or 10 Processor: Core 2 Duo 1.8Ghz (or equivalent AMD CPU) Memory: 2GB RAM Graphics: NVidia GeForce 6600, ATI/AMD Radeon X1300, or Intel G965 Express (Direct3D Hardware Feature Level 10) DirectX: Version 10 Network: Broadband Internet Connection Storage: 21GB Audio: DirectX 10 compatible sound chip or onboard audio capability with the latest sound drivers
recommended_requirements: Recommended OS: Windows® 10 Processor: Core i5-2xxx Quad Core or better Memory: 4GB RAM or better Graphics: NVidia GeForce GTX 4xx, ATI/AMD Radeon HD 5xxx, or Intel HD Graphics 4xxx (Direct3D Hardware Feature Level 11.0) or better DirectX: Version 11.0 or better Network: Broadband Internet Connection Storage: 21GB Audio: DirectX 10 compatible sound chip or onboard audio capability with the latest sound drivers

reviews.review_text: I've been playing this game on and off since it's launch and it has gotten better from those days. My perspective is from one who only plays PvE(Player vs Environment) content. I'd recommend you try this game if;  1) you are not bored with the tradional WoW type MMO (hotbar combat) 2) you are Star Trek fan 3) you like to play doll with your character(s) (the character customization in this game is awesome) 4) you can live with bugs popping up (The new VP promises that bugs will be fix fast but only time will tell) 5) you can resist(or don't mind gambling) since there are lock boxes in the game which gives out a top prize of ships(basically classes in the game), etc  BUT you can get all these things in game if you have enough in game assets to dabble in the exchange(auction house)  6) you don't mind the usual MMO grindfests which can get repetitive to farm better gear, etc 7) you are not a hardcore gamer 8) your internet connection to the servers is not crap  The gameplay itself is nothing to write home about and the main reason I'm still playing it is because it's the only Trek MMO out there. The game panders mostly to the casual crowd.  Contrary to some, the game in my opinion is not Pay to Win. You can have access to all the ships and gear if you grind enough currency to exchange for these items which other players put up in the auction house. Using real money is just a shortcut in the game.  Also this game features player created missions, some of which, are much better than the official ones. Don't forget to give some a try if you decide to try this game out.  In my opinion, Free to Play means demo and Star Trek Online's demo is surprisingly good in the sense that it's not restrictive like in some other MMOs. If your ISP does not suck and you can wait to download a 10GB or so game, give it a try and see if it's up your alley. Live long and prosper. \V/.

Star Trek Online. I have almost 2000 hours on record. But I do actually have way more than that. For a while I had a really weak computer and I played the game standalone on a the DVD cover release. Back when that still existed.  Where do I start?  Star Trek Online has been through two phases, one is now gone but I'll take you through it anyway. To see how it has evolved.  When Star Trek Online was released it was driven by Cryptic and released by Atari. Both on their own site, Steam and through DVD boxes in stores. At that time the game was really weak and lacking. There was no audio dialog or fancy cutscenes and the graphics were already a tad outdate. New content was barely released because of how small the team was. But we still had a lot of fun exploration missions, you could visit every star system even if that ment just flying around the planet and looking around. You also had to pay to play back then. You could buy playing time online or buying 'month' cards.  Then the big boss 'Perfect World Entertainment' came a long. Now this was a good and a bad thing. The good news is that since Perfect World has a lot more resources than small Cryptic. And Atari was just a publisher, this now ment that Star Trek Online had a big team with a lot of resources. This mean the game quickly evolved in a highly positive way.   Such as missions getting better and more complex, the introduction of even more advanced audio dialoge and cutscenes. The general story telling of the game got improved a lot. There have also been way more updates and patches and they even just recently overhauled the graphics engine and it looks all quite nice. The ships have also been re-done since Beta days to make them look more realistic. Most even have brand new, made from scratch models and textures. So the graphics now compared to release are amazing.  That being said. The game is now free to play and everything ingame can be accessed without real life money. Though it'll take you ages to do that. But since the game is free, and there's something you really want I don't see a problem buying it for real money. You support the developers.  While the developers do not always pay attention to small bug reports that have been sitting on the forums or tickets for ages. They do fix serious issues. For example one time, I deleted my main character that I'd have for years and after 2 weeks I got a mail saying they managed to recovery the character. They are also good at cracking down mean players and annoying 'gold sellers'.  While the story driven content and graphics have been improved, togheter with general gameplay some things have been 'broken' as well.  For example, most systems in the Galaxy cannot be entered unless you have a specific mission. Almost all systems have a patrol mission, where you enter.. Explore, kill some bad guys or something. But when you've done that once. You are NOT allowed to repeat the mission on the same character.  The story arc is also 'shared' for all the factions in the game. Each faction has some unique missions but in the end they follow the same line of missions but it's done in a way so it's somewhat different and okay in my eyes.  They removed the exploration missions. In the old days the game itself generated a random star system, a random map and a totally random mission. So nothing was ever the same. Almost. Anyway it was a fun way to get some diversity in the game when you've done all your leveling and stuff. This was sadly removed because it did not 'feel up to the game standards' but we have not seen a replacement.  So when you're done playing all the story missions and done all the patrol missions. There are also some mini missions on Starbases and some planets, but again. These are non replayable. All you got is PVE and PVP. PVE is mostly dead but if you get in a fleet you can run private sessions. PVP is somewhat broken if you can call it that. It means the 'general' player can't really compet here because of how out of control DPS has gotten. But that's something you can google. Of course if you wanna' get into DPS it can be quite fun for those who love that.  But in short, Star Trek Online is an amazing game that brings the Trek universe to full scale in my eyes. You can visit and see all the locations from the show. All the starships are included in great detail along with a few new ones. The game also take place in 2409-2410. That's way ahead of Star Trek Voyager, Deep Space 9 and The Next Generation. That allows the game to have technology that wasn't in the series. For example personal shield generators and stuff like that. It works out great with the game setting and it does bring the feel of this is what Star Trek would evolve too.  There is a lot of Star Trek lore in the game to enjoy, everything from food items to a name mentioned. Or just a location or event in the series. You can also meet a lot of Star Trek Characters complete with audio dialog from their actors. Like the Doctor played by Roberto Picardo, Tuvok by Tim Russ and even Neelix by Ethan Phillips. There are also some people from Star Trek Enterprise etc.  The game also now focuses heavily on what happend in Star Trek Voyager, Deep Space 9, The Next Generation, Enterprise and even The Original Series. For example a lot of the deep episodes on the TV shows that was not really fully explained. Like Yeasterday's Enterprise.. The Temporal Cold War. The Iconians.. Stuff like that are explained in the game and it's just amazing.  But you don't need to be a Trekkie to play. You can still pick up on a lot of the jokes etc. There is also a lot of customization involved in the game. You have a lot of options when it comes to designing your character. It even puts the character creator in Saints Row to shame, and that's saying something. You can also customize your starship and mix parts. For example a Galaxy Class can have different nacelle's.. (Engines for you non Trek fans).  Anyway to this day, even though it's free the game gets new content quite often compared to other MMO's. The only other bad side is that the game community can be quite... Hostile. So it'll be hard to make friends and feel welcome. Try to ignore that, as some of the players including myself are awesome and nice.  In short, this is an amazing game. Especially if you are a Trekkie. And the fact that it's free, it doesn't hurt to try. Does it?  Also the game runs well on my system, though I have a very powerful system. Sometimes you do get a tad huge FPS drops if there are a lot of clicky powers etc. But that's just the game slowing down. Not you. Also on the Steam Page it's mentioned that it can run on 'Intel HD Graphics' this is only newer generation. The game was developed to work on Intel HD Graphics so everyone can play it. I tested it on my laptop with a Core i5-5500 2.20 GHz CPU, 8 GB RAM and Intel HD Graphics 5500. The game runs quite well with graphics set to low. You can have things like character detail, high detail objects and textures maxed out. But fancy things such as lighting and shadows must be off. Still runs quite well on a 'non gaming laptop'.

An amazing game all considered! To me it's just incredible to see how much it has grown and improved since three years ago when I started playing. It has it's defects, I won't lie to you. But it's definitely the most original mmo experience I've ever had, the most vision inspired and honest endevour! There's plenty to do, space combat is great, complex and exciting. As are the mechanics of gameplay, in general. Ground combat is ok, but improvents are constantly in development. Also, to be honest, pvp play falls a bit short at the moment, even though after just a first match you can realize that there's huge potential, and the community around pvp is remarkable (they even started an open school!). Gameplay is very story-driven, and most of the narrative inside it's absolute TOP NOTCH Star Trek fiction -they have brillian writers. It is, I think, the only place where new Trek episodes are being made at the moment. It's been showcased in many mmo rpg reviews and also won a 'best free to play' title a year ago.  If the game is not enough for you, and if you feel like it, there's an integrated editor called 'The Foundry' where every player can create their own episodes (=quests, pve campaigns), and upload them into the game for everybody to play, review and vote (there's a periodic competition with prizes for the winner)! The content is limitless!  What else can I say... I just loved it from day one and I will keep playing it, as I know Cryptic is committed and passionate about making it a little better every day!  Just try it out and decide for yourselves, it's free to play for crying out loud!! :D Live long and prosper!

As a Founder, with a lifetime account I will admit up front my opinion may contain a small amount of bias. Since I have not had to pay for the game, following Beta, I have had the fortune of enjoying it off and on at leisure. STO, has evolved since the beginning, with a whole new research and development system, additional episodes with a magnificent ton of canon content, STO allows players to experience up close, old favorite worlds, species we've grown up with for decades, and new, powerful enemies of ancient Trek lore, back to cause destruction. The graphics are mid-level, but the game makes up for those shortcomings by allowing players to fully customize their ships, officers, characters, and more.   One evil little caveat, this game is notorious, and I do literally mean Notorious for it's legion of micro-transactional content. I do not agree with the level the current owners of ESO take micro-transactions. I believe that paying out of pocket for the chance to wear Star Trek: The Motion Picture costumes, is a little overboard. This is just one example, there are hundreds more. Each has to be bought separately with coins from the in-game store. Coin's can be purchased with real money. As a huge fan of Trek, up until about 2 years ago I had purchased everything the in-game store allowed, and the sheer volume of new content available by micro-transaction was so high, I didn't have the hundreds or even thousands of dollars necessary to keep up with it. Sadly, there is a lot of content, including actual pay to win ships, consoles, etc. which may be out of the casual gamers reach. If one can overlook this glaring and elephant in the room sized flaw the game has, the game can be fun. The episodes are like playing an interactive star trek series. It has a lot of room for growth and potential. I would recommend giving it a try if you haven't already.

Very fun game with a lot going on. Was not initially expecting much, but was pleasantly surprised. The game offers a variety of playstyles, ships, equipment, and crew controls. The fact that you can get a huge capital ship by simply getting to the endgame and not needing to pay for one was a great surprise. The seasonal events were a blast. As a star trek fan is really made me feel at home. By the time i hit max level i found myself actually buying things with real money just so my character would look all the more cool hehe. Definitely give it a shot if you are an mmo or startrek fan.

Absolutely fantastic game. I've played for years and yes, sometimes the content in the new seasons leaves something to be desired, and the cost for zen-store content is a bit on the greedy side, but for a free-to-play title I'm happy to tithe forward a few bucks every month for a few extra nice-to-have cosmetic goodies. The foundry (permitting self-written content) is fantastic. The replayability is high and frankly - being able to pop online and fly a ship around the Star Trek universe for a bit provides a nice break from the daily grind. NOT a game for those who want PVP - but since I'm happily well in the PVE preferring body of gamers I've got zero issues with that. There are some variances from Star Trek canon, but the development team at PW seems to have continued to work on keeping to what's reasonable for the universe as Roddenberry framed it. The variety of story lines can sometimes come across as a mash-up that doesn't mesh terribly well, but the quantity and variety vastly outweigh any annoyance at those moments. Highly recommend giving it a go - as a f2p option you've literally got nothing but some time to lose and the chance to get to know a hell of a good game.
Good game. Horrifying customer service.
Lots of content and easy to start out. Fun to play with friends

Beware! Purchasing Zen via Steam will cause that currency to be locked for a week or more, usable only on items that are untradable (account bound). That means you can't use the dilithium exchange. This lock will last until 'your purchase has been confirmed in order to prevent fraud.'   I am currenty at the seven day mark. I tried to purchase more zen from the official website immediately following and that was locked also even though it has a confirmation number. Filing a GM ticket will not correct this, as PWE really wants you to not use Steam for purchases.

I decided to play this game on a whim awhile back. I tried to play this game before about a year or two ago and it was just a screwed up cluster of junk on my screen. Now that I have come back and tried to play it again, it seems that a lot has been changed for the better in my opinion.  The grind wasn't that bad at all. I never found myself having to grind because of being underleveled and whatnot. By playing the episodes and playing on the event weekends (2x weekends, etc), I easily made it to Lv 55 in about 100 hours. Keep in mind that I casually played this game for about 2 - 3 hours a day.  The only thing I bought was 2k Zen, so I could buy my favorite ship, the Excelsior Refit Class. I was Lv 50 when I bought it. I could have gone with a T6 ship, but I already had the free Kobali Cruiser and I prefer the Excelsior Refit due to it's dashing good looks.  If there is one big problem with the game, it would be the ground missions. The ground mechanics are extremely boring. They really should focus on just scrapping the current ground system and re-building it with a more dynamic/controllable.

Star Trek Online is the ultimate experience for aspiring Starfleet officers. Rising through the ranks is gruelling and demanding but never boring. Command a starship, explore planets, meet new and old characters. This game is for all the Star Trek fans everywhere.

It's a f2p mmo. With all the things that makes ppl hate 'em. So if you aren't a farmer like me, prepare to pay. Otherwise it's fun with nice space portions and ground is kinda there to. It has multiple Classes: Tac - the useful dd one, Engineer - implodes less than the others and Science - which is the heal/cc guy which is kinda just there.  Also you can choose your ship independantly from your class so yay for squishy tanks and DDs trying to tank and going boom.  In short I like this and recomend it, unless you have, like me, that 'oh shiny new ship' sickness.
Aside from a few bugs here and there, it's a great game to play.

It has huge storyline across 3 fully developed campaigns. the space battles are incredible, the variation of ships is staggering and the graphics are beautiful. the game does suffer however because of its ground combat because you will find yourself dying over and over to try and complete a mission. so summarise if you love star trek play this game. if you love sci-fi play this game. if you like giant laser fights play this game.
Qutie fun if you put enough time and effort into it.
Been playing since beta and still very fond of the game. So many new features added since launch and it just keeps getting better.
I am an avid Sci-Fi'er and this is a very fun game to play. There is not much about the game that I don't like. If you like Star Trek a little this is definatly a must.
To boldly go where no Lawie has gone before... if you are a trekkie, this will be your game ;)
Meow thiss iss awwessomm!!
In one word. Epic.
best game to play

And the lag disconnection issues account that was so bad i even cry a little because i love star trek. However 2014 The game is change a lot. New contend new ships new missions new events is it good yah it is, is it the best hell no. But its for sure 200% better than at start. If you're a Star Trek fan, then you'll want to play this. Obviously, PW makes their money by having microtransactions. However, despite this, it's still equitable for the F2P player. As the game description says, it's like being inside the show. Sector narration is done by Leonard Nimoy, Michael Dorn reprises his role as Worf and there are other familiar characters. If you're a Star Trek fanboy like me, then you'll see this game as a time suck. It's not the most visually stunning game out there but it's a lot of fun.  Edit 1: Recently, Tim Russ reprised his role as Tuvok during a Dyson Sphere event.   Edit 2: Now that I have more time on record, I can add a few things. My view about the game above is still the same. However, I will take the time to add a few things. As I said before, it helps if you're a Star Trek fan to begin with. You get to play with the ship types you saw in the different series and you get to visit the places you could only see on TV. I will caution you that the story takes place some 30 years after the events of the last Star Trek movie (no, not the new ones...I mean Nemesis). If you take that into consideration, you'll realize that it's a whole new take on the franchise.   Edit 3: I mentioned before that there are microtransactions. Really, the best ships are there and it wouldn't hurt to drop some money on Zen to get a few of them. That being said, you seriously don't have to. What you're really paying for are the consoles that come with them that give you some neat abilities. When you hit max level, you can get all kinds of equipment by running PvE/PvP queues that evens the playing field. So, you don't need to buy anything at all.   Edit 4: With the Legacy of Romulus update they did, the current mechanics seem to favor the Romulans since you can choose a side. Their ships seems to have the advantage in fights and function in multiple capacities. That being said, the disparity isn't actually there. Each race has their strong suit and each race is deficient somwhere.
Fantastic game if you're a fan of Star Trek. Actaully, it's a great game even if you're not a fan.

Star Trek online is a game which follows in the footsteps of the franchise T.v shows in that the story and characters are always respectful of the lore but like the new movies alot of the plot revolves around time-travel and dimensional travel but so what, it seems the new season is focused on previously untold and unexplored concepts around Millenia-dormant threats from numerous ancient races which push the boundaries of the lore. I think many of the story mission sagas would actually make good comics or novels but most players lament not having conversation choices impact the story in a significant way, even though there are many opportunities to play as evil or good. The lengthy Rep system and new Research schools and specialization trees cretainly breathed life into the game for dedicated players, as well as new ships available to all players who complete events during winter and summer. 'No player need be left behind' in terms of ships and equipment, if you trade longer playtime for an outright buy. Important here to note is the store in this game has exorbitant prices, a ship can cost you $30 dollars only to be outclassed later and there are many 'packs' that range in the hundreds of dollars, 'WTH'? right? but believe me, I've played a long time and any player can earn and buy any ship the free way and it won't take THAT long maybe like a saving a month in-game at the most for a good ship. Lock box ships can also be purchased on the exchange I know many people who get them this way. All in all, what with events and discounts and giveaway's and dedication, I don't feel leftout as a non-subscriber and over the years I can say the game earned what I spent, at least I wasn't dumb enough to get into Lockbox keys but If you want to gamble 100's of dollars you deserve a good ship! crazy. Anyway, Graphics are good with many story options, some actually stunning enviroments like summer Risa, hours of fun for Trek fans or sci-fi ship combat fans, although ship combat is some of the best I've played, its done in a third person view with a more stategic take in that the skills and manouvering you use in combat are all important since all combat is auto-aimed. Same with ground combat strategy is all important and headshots non-existant but for a skill tree which gives a crit bonus for aimed shots. Anyhow, I would say check it out, I don't offer many criticisims because the game is quite open ended and everyone finds a different nche of activities they like, Over-all it's impressive work but I would say suffers like all MMO's because they also incorporate alot of 'mindless' grindiness into into it, if you know what I mean, something like being presented with a mountain of dull paperwork to do to get some rewards but again it's up to the player if they 'feel' like it or not.

Played a tonne of this just after it went F2P and before it went on Steam.  Really enjoyable space combat game combined with a pretty lackluster ground combat portion. The story missions are pretty enjoyable compared to most MMO's, and make you feel involved in the plot rather than just as a witness to it. Also unlike other MMOs you aren't stuck doing gathering/kill quests to advance, but instead you are doing stuff to advance storylines. It was refreshing to play through an MMO that felt more like a proper story-based game.  At times it feels like a strange fanfic of what happens next in the original universe, but it's still Star Trek. Sure the DS9 and Voyager continuations can make little sense, but it's still a fun time to see those characters return.  If you're a Star Trek fan there is more than enough in here to delight you for a good long while.

It doesn't do ground combat anywhere as good as World of WarCraft, Dungeons & Dragons Online, DC Universe Online, or Star Wars: The Old Republic. However it does space nonsense way better than Star Wars: The Old Republic.  So if you wanna fly around shooting crap and you have a choice between STO and SWTOR, pick the one with less letters.
Great game, lots of fun and many missions. Never ending fun! 120+ hours of gameplay

I am not a Trekkie (I still love the series), or a big mmorpg player (tho I have played a large amount of them)..... I got hooked with this one. Good story lines and user created content, with very satisfying gameplay.    I LOVE the space combat, the effects and explosions are well done. There is a certian kind of fun to be had blasting through an enemy's shields and then having to punch through their hull, only to end up with not one....but 2 gratifying explosions. In the few month I have been playing there have been repeated updates and new content added, with the sandbox growing in size. There have been bugs. MANY bugs. But the Devs are actually working on them, many have even been fixed by the next patch.
This is a Free to Play game and the model that it uses is the best one out there. As an MMO it's pretty standard, but the story and constant updates are great.

This 'is' Star Trek, from simple diplomacy mission and transporting dignataries to thier destination to repleaing a Borg or Klingon Invasion. Missions of exploration and defense. This game is very underated by some but a blast to play. The space combat is very well done and worth the download alone.

While some of the gameplay depends on the depth of your wallet, most of it is enjoyable with great graphics and a decent interface. If you are willing to drop money in it then you can increase your gameplay experience, ad if you aren't then you might want to stay away from the PvP matches.
Fun, thats all ya need to frickin know. also you don't need to know much about Star Trek to know what the bloody hell is going on so YAY.
This game is very fun, I really Enjoy playing it, You should too.
200 hours on record. Obviously it's a good game.
extremely addicting
Photon torpedoes full spread, deflector online .. wait , on my mark, fire, half impulse dead ahead ... :))))

The game has a lot of nice custimizable features for your character and crew. As long as you keep getting new equptment it's actually pretty good at keeping your quests to not being too hard for your level and having a lot of activities to do. For the most part the community is very helpful and nice but there are a lot of horrible people as well to watch out for but it's not very previlient.  There are some quests who do feel over powered and just can cause you some problems but if you just get friends to help it'll usually cut the difficulty down, which is the nice thing, you can do your quests with friends and help each other out very easily. There are a couple things you can't do together but for the most part you can do a lot.  Creating your own stories is a lot of fun as well though I haven't messed around much with the feature.

Perhaps one of the best MMORPG's I've player where being a free member can actually still achieve something great !
Getting better and better with every update.

The best free to play MMO for sure. The game is leaps and bounds better now than it was at release. The starship combat is some of the funnest combat I've played in any game period. The ground combat is vastly improved and now it's actually fun. I still wish they would add true exploration to the game, but there is so little to complain about with this game. One of my all time favs.

Amazing game, and it's free, at first I was worried that my computer couldn't handle the graphic intensity of the game, but it didn't matter because the game set itself to the lowest setting, allowing me to enjoy an 8bit Star Trek online. 10/10 Would 8Bit again.
If you play this only for story, it's very good game. I only play this when they release 'new DLC' . But if you want play PvP better prepare some cash...

Star Trek has always been a dream MMO for me to play and when I first saw this I knew I had found my one home on the internet.  I installed it and created my account and I was truly amazed by just the amount of immersion they have built into the game. Ypou start by creating your character, You can choose between Federation, Klingon Empire or Romulan Empire... I picked Starfleet of course!  Upon creating your character I was expecting your normal 6 races that were peoples most favs but I soon learned that you could go as far as being Andorian and even a Trill(Joined or not) BUT it does not stop there, They have also included the tools to create your own Alien Race complete with special abilities custom looks and the lot. Imagine Spore Creature Creator in an MMO!   The Tutorial began and I was celebrating graduation from starfleet Academy which for me was a real shame because I would liked to have spent some more time and perhaps even my first 10 levels just learning about the game and the Star Trek Universe. I mean would you take up the chance to do a class on Warp Engineering?  This is where the excittment stopped for me, There is ground combat but I refuse to even Awknowledge that part of the game as its severly lacking in every possible way. (I remember one time I was being chased around a tree by a Klingon... all my friends just stood and laughed at me)   Space battles are extremely intense and provide a great bit of stress relief though I felt there could have been a little more.  SUGGESTION: Not something I can really complaoin about but I'm going to rant and suggest it here... this is Star Trek and there is no ability to command your ship from the captains chair... I want to be able to walk around my ship issuing commands to my crew, not steering and fighting in 3rd person from outside the ship!   Now that is all I can say but would like to also note it is a Theme Park MMO and I find these rather boring so this is not one I have played a lot of but it is one that has earnt itself a spot on my shelf and it will remain there defiantly.
Players are pretty nice for the most part. Although the end game content is lacking, the player's ability to make their own missions can make up for this and appear to your RPG side.
Played on and off since launch, very impressed with the evolution of this game. Would recommend anyone to try this.
Very cool space combat.
Even if you are not a Star Trek fan, this game is fun, fast, friendly and best of all free!!

I came to this game back on the free to play launch. I for the most part played nightly up until a year to two ago. While the game is a great game one of the biggest down sides that caused me to stop playing the game is the constant grind to level up just so you can play the next story driven mission. Sure it is easy to level up but it just gets old doing the same thing over and over again just to get to some new content. The game when I came to it wasnt too bad but with the release of the fleet bases the game became a very huge dilithium sink which is now starting to level off some as dilithium values have dropped as majority of people have already finished their bases. If you're a Trek fan, there's a lot to love. You'll recognize people, places, things, and plots from across Trek's 50 year history, you can even play a TOS-era character as an alternate start method. Gameplay is very combat heavy, but this *is* an MMO.   The F2P model is very fair (if you're not trying to PVP at a high level, anyway), and you can finish the game without spending a single dime if you wish. Zen (the store currency) can be bought with in-game resources, but even not counting that you can use entirely free ships and weapons to finish the story and dive into the endgame, it's just a bit harder. The endgame grind can, admittedly, be a slog. Mostly in time, not in repetiveness if you plan it right, but it's still there. That grind is only as important as you want it to be though.  STO is not without its problems, but that's not uncommon with MMOs. Yes, there's bugs, yes, it can be laggy, but for most people it's not so bad as to hurt the experience. If you want a fun romp full of Trek nostalgia, STO is worth a look.

To boldly go where no series has gone before!   Star Trek Online has come a long way from the 49.99 shelf price I picked it up at. From beaming down to that alien world of your favorite Star Trek episode, to fighting the Borg across the sector. Each piece culminates into a game anyone who enjoys Sci-fi can love. Trekkies of course get the opportunity to visit each of those scenes they loved most in Star Trek.  The current iteration of Star Trek Online is quite simply put, 'Marvelous' and only getting better with the addition of the Delta Quadrant. PVE is the main focus, but PVP is possible in specified battle zones. Surprisingly, and a wonderful touch in my opinion—has been the growing addition of Voice Actors for a number of main quests, and most importantly, voice acting by actual Star Trek actors, come to replay their digital roles.   Some of STO’s original voice acting flops, but they have gotten very good at putting the proper emotion behind their voice actor’s character. Each new addition is far better than the last.   More than anything else, in this game…the story is perhaps the cherry on top. Wrapping the player into a universe that is similar, and yet so very different from the shows we used to watch.   I highly recommend this game for anyone who enjoys Science Fiction of any kind, just wants to kill things in space ships, or loves a good story. Oh, and of course if you are a trekkie, why aren’t you playing already?

Although updates to the game can mean a lengthy wait while downloading, especially if you haven't played for a few weeks, the constant adition of replayable side missions makes it a game you can easily come back to and enjoy again and again.  two thumbs up to this game

Star Trek Online: An MMO RPG where you begin as a captain of a 'Miranda-Class', 'ShiKahr-Class' or 'Centaur-Class' Light Cruiser of the Federation. Travel across the Alpha, Beta, Gamma and Delta quadrants of the Milky Way Galxy, fighting numerous opponents such as Klingons, Romulans, Cardassians and many many more. Pilot your ship in ever-challenging combat scenarios and send yourself along with an away team to different planets to fight intense ground combat battles. You will ascend through the ranks of the Federation and gain new and more powerful ships along the way, choosing either a Science, Engineering or Tactical path as you become one of the most powerful captains the Federation has ever seen.   So I have around about 45 or so hours on this game on steam, around the same amount off of it also, and let me tell you it's my favourite game outright on PC. It's one of those games where it's so rich in lore and exciting combat, I can hardly get off of it. The story has clearly been designed by people passionate about all Star Trek lore, including the newer J.J. Abrams movies, as you'll see in the story. The episodes you play are exciting, clever and challenging, so much so that I find myself engulfed in a battle against a huge Romulan D'Deridex warbird in my reasonably large Intrepid Long-Range Science Vessel.  The combat GUI and controls are very nicely assigned allowing fluid and immersive combat on ground and exhilarating space combat, paired with gorgeous 3D visuals and beautiful particle effects it fully immerses you into the Star Trek galaxy. This game is beautifully designed by a great team; Cryptic have successfully made a game woprthy of being canon with the Star Trek Universe.  So I should do a traditional 'Pros V Cons' list so here goes.  Pros:  ~ Great Servers, never experienced any lag and loading times for large areas are decent.  ~ Nice Selection of Ships, huge lists of small shuttles all the way to the monstrous 'Obelisk Carrier'... it's big.  ~ Great Story Missions, facing a huge selection of enemies from all the Star Trek TV and Movies.  ~ Beautiful Visuals, maps and particle effects are great, along with the ships too.  ~ Lovely community, never seen any kind of hate war on the chat, only people willing to trade and help eachother out.  ~ Combat difficulty is dependent on your level, not the mission order.  ~ Custom Player, Bridge Officers, Ship, Ship Name AND Ship Designation Number (NCC-1701 style)  ~ EPIC MUSIC, nuff said.  Cons:  ~ Pay to play is evidently the case for higher level players wanting more ships or ships of better quality.  ~ Some ground tasks within missions can seem more like a fool's errand more than 'Investigating' however of course that sometimes is the life of a starfleet officer.  ~ Patch download the first time is quite substantial and is always increasing with every update.  ~ Really Nitpicking, the planet's aren't full scale.   All together I completely recommend this genious brilliant game, you'll enjoy it massively if you've evr appriciated any star trek series OR film. Seriously, start the download now.

So right off the bat, I'm going to make the claim that if you're a Star Trek fan, you'll find something to love about this game.  Whether it's the episodic campaign that draws heavily upon the series and films. Or the vast overworld that allows you to beam down to many of the iconic locations you've come to know and love, such as Deep Space Nine, Starfleet Academy, Earth Stardock, Risa, and, taken directly from the most beloved film of the series, Paradise City from ST V. (Kidding.) Or just being able to run around your own ship or shuttle, most of which are inspired by, or are of the same class as, the ones from the show/films, and pilot it around the galaxy. There's something in this game for everyone.  Since most people here have already covered the big parts of the game, I'll point my own personal list of Pros and Cons:    PROS:   - Fantastic Campaign:  The devs for STO are big time Trek fans, and you'll definitely discover this once you start making your way through the campaign of your choice: Starfleet, Romulan, or Klingon. Each episode is formatted like an episode of the show, most of which are heavily inspired by plotlines from the show and films. Some of the episodes even continue the stories of some ST characters. Some devolve into shoot-'em-ups, but most --  especially  the recent ones -- are 100% Trek, on par with the show. There are also player-created missions available to play through by way of the Foundry, which is awesome and something I wish more MMOs would incorporate.  -  Frequent Updates:  Cryptic update the game with major episodic content a few times a year, most of which have featured actors reprising their roles from the series, such as Michael Dorn (Worf), Tim Russ (Tuvok), and Denise Crosby (Tasha Yar). Leonard Nimoy also narrates many key parts of the game in-character as Spock. Each new episode has added new story content, dailies, and general updates -- and all of them have been free. We've had one full-fledged expansion,  Legacy of Romulus , and another one on the way in October called  Delta Rising .  -  The Star Trek Experience:  A lot went into making the game feel like a genuine Trek experience. The general atmosphere, the scale of the overworld, the missions, the visuals, locations, and characters. You take command of your own ship, and you can pretty much roll up any character you can imagine: from the stock races, such as Human, Vulcan, Romulan, Klingon, Betazoid, Trill, Orion, etc., to a custom alien race that you can define. There are also a lot of RP opportunites: Dabo(!), asteroid mining, ship interiors, and seasonal events. Just a lot of great stuff.  -  F2P Model:  If I had to make a list of the most ethical F2P MMOs on the market... it would be a short list, but STO would be near the top. All of the story, PvE, and PvP content is free, as are all the updates. Most of the things Cryptic are making money off of are cosmetic items (uniforms, ship interiors/exteriors), ships (but the free ships are just as competitive), and services like inventory space, character slots, bank space, etc. The two things that I would count against it are the lockboxes, which can be easily ignored, and the two races locked behind a paywall, though with nearly infinite races available to you, it doesn't make much of a difference in my opinion. With a model like this, I've been happy to support it since I started playing.    KHANS:   - Sector Space:  Initially, it's no big deal, but after some time you start to realize how unintuitive Sector Space can be, sectioned off the way it is. Can you land here, orbit, or do nothing? Why are there invisible walls in space? There's an event here, but is anyone participating? What does the event even entail? Cryptic have stated in the past that they want to give Sector Space an overhaul, which would be awesome, but we still have it for now.  -  Instance Stagnation:  There are a lot of PvE and PvP instances to queue up for. People play a select few, but most have stagnated -- not from lack of players, just lack of interest. I'd much rather them not be there if no one's going to play them, so that Cryptic would be able to put more focus on the ones people still enjoy.  -  Community:  Do yourself a favor and find a good fleet that you can get along with, because the community in STO, at least the vocal part, might just drive you insane. This is nothing new to online games, but it seems abnormal in a Trek game. Part of the reason might be how fragmented chat is in STO, which makes moderation rather difficult. Making chat universal across individual sectors would make things better, I think, but for now reading ESD chat might just make you go blind.  I think that about covers it! Like I said, if you're a Star Trek fan, you owe it to yourself to give this a try, especially now that we're on the verge of a new expansion.  Live long and prosper!

Star Trek Online (STO) is a solid MMORPG with tons of customization option for those who are willing to work for it. It is not, however, a good Star Trek game.   For me, the main draw of Star Trek isn't so much the science fiction, which let's face it, is on the silly side. It is the characters, the dynamics between the crew that makes it interesting. In-game, however, crew members are treated as little more than equipment, so that personal connection is gone. You gain the ability to customize your officers however you want, true, but you lose what makes them characters.  Another problem of the game is the randomly generated sidequests. Sure, it's fun to pretend that you are the star of your own Star Trek show, routinely investigating strange species, artifacts, and negative space wedgies, but the mad-lib style of quest generation means that after a while, all these quests seem to blur together. So aside from the story quests - which are well done, by the way - none of the other content is memorable.  The saving grace for these sidequests is the Foundry, which allows users to create their own quests and stories. Sturgeon's Law is in full effect here; 90% of the custom content is lackluster, but the other 10% makes it worthwhile.  While the game has problems that prevent it from being truly great, I would still recommend it for MMO gamers. The universe feels big, the ship-to-ship combat is frantic but tactical (although sometimes you fight with the UI more than the enemy), and the amount of reference to the Star Trek shows can make Star Trek enthusiasts giddy. If these sound exciting, that this is the game for you.

Update: 7 February 2016;  It's a fun game to play for a while, especially for fans of the series. There are plenty of different ships, including the main ships from each series; James T. Kirk's Constitution-class Cruiser, Jean-Luc Picard's Galaxy-class Cruiser, Benjamin Sisko's Defiant-class Escort, Kathryn Janeway's Intrepid-class Long-range Science Vessel, Jonathan Archer's NX-class Escort. You can also find some movie-specific ships in the game, such as the Excelsior-class.  You could also go for a Klingon or Romulan Republic character, which opens up other ships and options, as well as unique story routes for these characters.  Endgame is a lot of PvE/PvP grinding, but what MMO does not have that? STO at least offers a variety of ways in which one can 'grind'. Such as research and development, special missions for duty officers or admiralty ships, and a reputation system with its own special rewards.  There is also room for daytrading on the exchange, although item prices seem regulated by a few dozen players who have large stocks of special items laying around on alt-characters and alt-accounts. Not too infrequently I have come across items which are no longer obtainable in the game, bought one or two to see if the price would rise, only to see five more of the same item put up on the marketplace within minutes, as if the sales triggered them to be posted.  PvE missions are all doable with items obtainable through in-game currency, but if you are looking to do PvP, it is more of a pay-to-win situation. The more competitive ships require ZEN to buy them or items for them, and while you can trade Dilithium for ZEN, at a cost of 316:1 it's simply not worth it.  The community is decent, and the new armada system allows fleets to work together more, so it's definitely worth looking at playing it with some friends.

I have been a fan of the 'Star Trek' TV show for many years. If you're a fan of the TV show, this game will give you a lot of nostalgia and will make you feel like you're part of the Star Trek universe.   PROS: - You will get to choose your own new starship around every 10 levels, or basically with a new promotion. - There are LOTS of missions and some of the stories are pretty long and interesting. You will have to accomplish multiple tasks (even puzzles) to progress further in your story. - You get to choose your own uniforms, which includes the colors and looks. - You get to travel through many sectors of space with beautiful views of stars, nebulas, and planets if you choose to approach a particular solar system. - You do not have to buy anything in order to progress through any story or missions - this is an option for if you want to get a cool looking ship or other features. - You get to choose what alien race you will be, hence deciding your organization as well. Will you choose to side with the Federation, the Klingon Empire, or the Romulans? - Get ready to immerse yourself with popular characters from Star Trek, such as Worf and Sela in later stories! - Leonard Nimoy, aka Spock, sometimes narrates the prologues of what's happening.  CONS: - I used to crash a lot when I first started this game, but now I crash maybe once or twice every hour or so. - The graphics sometimes get glitchy and there are times where when the character is talking, their mouth movements do not match the speaker. - The background music tends to get too repetitive, and personally feel like there should be additional background music, especially when exploring space.  Overall this is a highly enjoyable game, even for those who do not know much about Star Trek.

While I am no Star Trek fan myself, I can say, with pride, that this is a game I can truly enjoy playing. If I find it interesting, then any Trekkie can find this game to be a blast!  In this review, I will cover the most famous mechanics of the game, as well as the storyline and customization options for your character.  First off, I'll talk about space combat. Space combat in Star Trek Online is equipment-based. It means that, the higher the tier of your weapons, the better the damage and other side effects. Each officer has his/her own style of play. A Tactical officer can go in guns blazing and deal extreme amounts of damage (with the drawback being that a ship that fits a Tac Officer the most is a glass cannon), while an Engineer can go in and provide heals to his or her teammates on the frontline from a Cruiser-type ship. A Science officer can provide special buffs and debuffs that can periodically repair a damaged hull, or add additional armor plating, or cloud the sensors of enemy ships, confusing them. All in all, whatever profession you choose, you will feel a difference in gameplay.  Same goes for ground combat. On the ground, a tactical officer is the biggest damage dealer, the engineer is a trap-layer and a tank, while a science officer provides medical buffs. Combat is also equipment-based. The higher the tier of your weapon, the more damage and side effects.  For trading, there is an Auction House system (Exchange in the game) that provides an easy way of locating what you want to buy, or check the price of what you want to sell.  There is premium currency in the game, called ZEN, that can be either bought, or (Here comes the good part) earned in the game by exchanging Dilithium crystals. Dilithium crystals can be found literally anywhere, but to turn them into useful currency, you need to refine them first. Sadly, there is a limit on refining, as in, you can refine only 8000 Dilithium every day. However, a person with enough patience can gather enough Dilithium to buy literally everything in the game.  Customization. The character customization, as is traditional to Star Trek, is limited ONLY to Humanoids. Even an ''alien'' species is limited to looking nearly like a Human. This is the main drawback of a universe filled with aliens. The aliens all look too Human that one can simply say they're all Human, only with genetic differences that make their faces appear different.  The storyline in Star Trek is as Trek-ish as it can get. A lot of talky-techy stuff, techno talk and so on. The story (For the Federation) starts off with the tutorial, where you are promoted to the seat of the Acting First Officer of a small, recently-commissioned cruiser. The cruiser, while on a test run, is ambushed by Klingons, the Captain is killed, and you assume the Captain's chair and become the commanding officer. This mission starts the Federation's struggle against the Klingon Empire and reveals a lot of dark secrets that the KDF has in store. As the story progresses, you encounter different empires seeking to destroy the Federation, like, the Cardassians, the Romulan Tal Shiar, the Borg, the Undine, and the Voth. Your mission, as an officer of the Federation's Starfleet, is to try and make peaceful contact with all the races, explore the galaxy, and protect those who are in need of protection.  All in all, this is a great game that anyone who has watched at least one Star Trek movie should play.

Star Trek Online is everything you're looking for... if what you're looking for is exactly an mmorpg set in the Star Trek universe. Frankly, if you're not a fan of Star Trek already, don't bother with this; but if you are, and what you want is more Star Trek that looks and feels like the real deal, then Star Trek Online is your go to. As far as MMOs go, STO is pretty clear cut, the same sort of thing, with some space battles thrown in - and I'm sure when it comes to gameplay there's a lot better out there. But when it comes to the feel and flow of the universe and the great stories, the Star Trek experience, well, that's what keeps drawing me back to this game when I inevitably give up on basically everything else.  The 'free-to-play' model is exactly what you think it is. You certainly don't need to pay to enjoy the game, but you have to shill out hundreds to get the really cool stuff. There is a market in the game that allows you to very slowly build up zen over time, but, you'd be there about a thousand years if you wanted to buy a ship with it. That said, the default ships are pretty cool... as long as you don't play a Romulan.  For the love of Odin don't ever play a Romulan. You will regret it once you've reached the max level and still can't get anything good looking or unique.

I don't consider myself a trekkie of any kind, but this mmo does a really nice job of capturing the Star Trek universe. I tend to enjoy games that really feel like an immersive enviorment. For example, Batman: Arkham City was a really great experience where I really felt in the batman universe. I believe that STO manages to accomplish this feeling of being in the Star Trek universe decently.  STO puts you in command of a starship, where you fly around the universe doing star trek lore inspired missions. Missions take place in both space and the ground. In space you control your ship in a third person view and on the ground you play as your custom designed captain (in third person).   Combat in general for this game is pretty simple. You can set your weapons to auto-fire in space and just fly around positioning yourself for the most ideal vantage point to shoot from. There are several different weapon types. Ground combat can either be done in a traditional action mmo format, or by using a targeting reticule. There are also 3 classes to choose from, each with differing abilities.  Customization in this game is pretty good. There are endless options to make a unique character. Ships can also be customized a bit.  The game does have its quirks however. There are tons of little things that could be polished more. Nothing that ruins the overall experience, but don't expect it to be a perfect game. Also the gameplay can get a bit stale after awhile. It feels like there is not really any super advanced tactics to anything. As a veteran mmo player this game didn't offer much challange.  The f2p elements are somewhat fair. The whole basis of the in game economy is that you can trade in game currency for real money currency to buy the real money items. However if you go that route expect to spend many days farming things to buy anything good.  Bottom line, this game is overall a good immersive experience if you enjoy sci-fi/star trek/mmo's. Don't expect a perfect game though.

Just for context, I played well over 300 hours of this game years back, when it was a relatively unknown, Pay-2-Play game, but got into shooters, and just a few weeks ago saw that it was on Steam. This review will be for the game in its state right now.   Graphics  Phenomenal. There is not an MMORPG that I've played with better visuals. Space combat is extremely visually pleasing. Different beam weapons have different looks (and sounds!), and each looks amazing. Torpedoes, cannons, and beam weapons all have their own amazing special effects. Not to mention, the ships are detailed, and reflections are realistic. Ships are varied, customization (covered below) has depth, and all lighting/shadow quality is top-notch. Ground characters are very detailed, with each character potentially looking completely different from the last (see customization for more detail). Textures, while not modern AAA quality, are high-quality, especially for such a large game. Easily the best looking MMO I've played    Gameplay  Gameplay is for the most part fun. Combat can be grindy at times, but it is an MMORPG, after all. Space combat is fun, controls are responsive and easy to learn (basically hold both mouse buttons to guide your ship and spam the spacebar to fire your weapons), and defeating enemies can pose a great challenge, but not too difficult to be impossible, lending a great sense of accomplishment at the end of a long, intense battle. Ground combat is lackluster, but manageable. The ground levels are sometimes quite large, but the game discourages exploration, in favor of more linear levels (which are sometimes not that linear), with set objectives you have to reach (go to X, defeat Y amount of enemies, etc.) but for the most part, it is doable. Generally, story missions are pretty funneled, so while the map may be large, much of it is inaccessable, and simply put there for the visuals, which is not a bad thing, as the ground visuals are, at times, gorgeous. It is an MMO, so something with programmable macros is recommended, though it's still very much playable with a standard 3-button mouse and QWERTY keyboard.    Story  Story is somewhat disinteresting, mostly due to the fact that any communication to the player is made through text (they've got voice actors for the newer episodes, so it becomes a little better in the later stages of the game). The gameplay style is at odds with much of the story, though, because most of the gameplay involves taking out enemies, when the game tries to push something a bit deeper, it just comes off as boring, though that might be my attention span at work. There's a fantastic little storyline in Drozana Station, which involves time-travel, that I found quite interesting, though, as well as a spook level, complete with maniacal laughs, and creepy poems, so that part was cool.  The new(-ish) story, surrounding Romulus and the Romulan faction (now playable!) is fantastic as well. I don't want to give any spoilers, but if you're looking for story, start out with a Romulan character. You won't be disappointed.   Customization  Extremely versatile. One of the most in-depth customizers I've seen in terms of characters, and the only customizer I've seen for vehicles in an MMO. For characters, you can choose a race (i.e. Human, Betazoid, Vulcan, etc.) or Alien, which pretty much means 'go wild.' You can spend half an hour perfectly tuning the decals on your Klingon-Vulcan cross's forhead, and then you hit 'Body' and it starts all over again. You can tune brow protrusion, eye width/depth/spacing/size/color, jaw width/height, and much more, and on the body, there are just as many options for leg or arm scaling, body shape and size, and yes, even breast size (hehehehe). After that, you choose the uniform for your character. You can stick with the classic uniforms (though TOS uniforms are pay-only), or go with the new uniforms created for the game, all of which offer tons of customizability and options. You can pretty much choose any color scheme for your character. There are uniform packs, such as classic uniforms (Enterprise Mirror Universe uniforms) or uniforms for specific characters (Seven of Nine or T'Pol, for instance). It's very easy to get lost in the customizer for lengthy amounts of time.   Canon  As you should be expecting, this, while still maintaining the storyline from the TV series and movies, does contain quite a bit of original story, but it isn't half-bad. A lot of it is focused around war, the main gameplay element being combat, after all, and in the later game focuses on the Borg and Undine, which makes for some cool missions. It's not nearly as off-canon as JJ Abrams' Star Trek, but it's unique enough to be interesting.   Pay  Do not listen to anybody who says that this game is 'Pay 2 Win' because it isn't. Here's what happens:  Get a free ship. Advance to level 10 Get another free ship. Advance to level 20 Get another free ship.  etc. through level 50. The end-game ships are not given to you, but the last ship you get (at 45 I believe) is still very competitive. Each ship is better than the last. Customization options are taken from three variants of the same ship, which you can pick and choose which parts to keep and which to change (i.e. Nacelle's from a Cheyanne class, but Saucer from the Dakota class). Paying, though, does not let you skip the grind to 50, which I think is absolutely amazing of them. When you do pay (which you will, if you like Star Trek enough) you will be rewarded with ships of previous levels with upgrades to make them competitive with newer ships, as well as some with fun gimmicks (like a Galaxy class that will separate into two sections) and they aren't very expensive at all. In the end, you're  supposed  to spend money, just because you want that one ship so badly, and it looks so cool.   Economy  In-game currencies are plentiful. There are different currencies which can be used to buy specific items, or there's an Exchange, which allows players to sell obtained items for Energy Credits, which are the main currency. Loot drops are VERY common, and you can get very good items from those loot drops, and the best part is, those loot drops didn't cost you anything, so if you don't need them, you can either discard them for some energy credits, or try to maximize your profit on the Exchange, and either way, you'll be making money.  Also, yes, there is a method of exchanging in-game currency, for paid currency, though the rate isn't favorable (which you shouldn't expect it to be), but it's there.    Overall, I'd give this game a solid 8/10. Very appealing visuals, combined with a good F2P model and okay storyline make this a great game for trekkies and general sci-fi fans alike.

I rate the game Star Trek Online 3/5. OK. And by 'OK' I mean not that bad but not that great either. I can recommend it to some but I personally don't want to play any more of it. I don't have the patience for it and I'm pretty sure I don't have the time either, not when there are so many other great games out there to play and so many other amazing game worlds to visit.  Essentially, Star Trek Online is a fun, highly detailed, hugely expansive adventure game with a very friendly community which is also severely hampered by awkward controls, an obtuse interface, repetitive game design and occasional bugs. This game requires a lot of patience and a lot of time.  +Good (at least adequate) graphics made to run on many different systems.  +Great character customization options (if the options can be deciphered).  +Lots of game options and settings.  +Truly expansive game with HUGE numbers of missions and locations (many of the space stations and such have the exact same layout unfortunately which gets highly repetitive).  +Large ship variety each of which have many subtle and non-subtle nuances about how they fight and what their load-outs can be.  +Free to play and not pay to win with an unusually friendly and helpful community which is always wanting to have new players to join in a game which mostly focuses on cooperative fights against computer controlled characters/events. There are lots of things you can buy with real money if you want to though. You can go up against other players too but most of them are extremely high-level and so have totally overpowered weapons and ships and shields who have been playing for years.  +There's a lot of stuff to see if you just want to fly around and look at stuff in your ship but that can get boring too. Afterall, you don't HAVE to do missions unless you want to see everything the game has to offer. But there is a lot you can see regardless, this being an at least partially open-world game. Lots of stuff for groups of friends to do also.  +/-You can play as the federation, Klingons or Romulans. I only played as the federation as I heard that the Klingons and Romulan factions don't feature campaigns or missions that are as well developed. Unfortunately the Borg and others are not a playable race. While there is a lot to see and do, the game will not let you do whatever you might be able to imagine. (I had hoped for a short while when I first heard about this game to be a good-guy rogue borg cube (we will assimilate some of you if you, you know, want to be assimilated) and I couldn't. Boo hoo!  +/-Classic, largely orchestral star trek music (which might not be for you if you don't like that very much or find it boring like I do) which can get repetitive over time and usually has a self-righteous feeling to it.  +/-Adequate though authentic sound effects.  +/-The game has levels to keep missions difficult and challenging and to reward you with leveled-up equipment as you progress. However, while thoughtful, as this increases replayability, this feature is implemented in a potentially buggy manner. If you enter a mission with a high-level friend and then that friend has to leave then you might be stuck in the mission and will need to find some way of escaping without being destroyed and thus automatically restarting the mission at that high level. You need to escape somehow and then re-enter it for the level to switch back to where your lower-leveled character is so you don't get almost instantly destroyed by high-level NPC enemies. The enemy difficulty leveling should ideally occur in real-time if possible. Still, this is not an issue which necessarily comes up a lot unless you have friends who are all very high level when you are not.  -Awkward controls even with the detailed keyboard and control re-mapping options. This game will make Just Cause 2's controls seem intuitive and streamlined. It might even make the controls in Mirror's Edge feel streamlined. System Shock 2's controls are easier. FreeSpace 2, a detailed space fighting sim, has easier controls than the space battles in this game.  -I mean, the game simultaneously seems to want you to use it like a menu and a 3d game which is usually obtuse. It is difficult to figure out how to do ANYTHING. Equipping a weapon or any other item is needlessly difficult. Indeed most menus, statistics and controls are needlessly obtuse and confusing giving this game a frustratingly long learning curve. I believe IGN's review said it best when it said something like how everything that is usually simple in a game is complex and everything that should be complex in a game (like traveling from one star system to another at warp speed) is oddly simple. This mostly just involves little, irritating things but all these little things combine to make a frustratingly difficult learning curve and this is the number one reason why I don't want to play this game anymore. Also, I have other games I'd rather play as a result despite this game's wonderful community. Even the interstellar map of the galaxy, for example, is hard to understand. Homeworld, this isn't.  -Occasional glitches and bugs throughout.  -The game's friendly AI is mediocre at best and the game's enemy AI is really bad. That's not the worst thing so far as fights are concerned though. The worst thing is that there simply isn't a lot of tactical depth to this game. Stay out of enemy weapon range (or line of sight if you are running around on the ground or a space station or inside a ship) and hit the enemy with your own weapons as quickly and as often as you can. Most tactical depth beyond basic maneuvering consists of figuring out which combination of abilities, special powers, shields and weapons to use at different times and against different groups of enemies (which is often not a very straightforward matter (which is fine in itself). However, this layer of tactical depth is often implemented in an extremely confusing manner which has a long and arduous learning curve to figure out (unless you have good friends (like I did) who will take an enormous amount of time to tell you what to do.) Unfortunately, once you have a combination of abilities, powers, shields and weapons selected, battles would have become a simple button-mashing frenzy if it were not for needing to wait for each item and weapon to recharge between each shot. You can opt to fire one weapon at a time though or fire them all at once in salvos (which is almost always best anyhow). Regardless, after you've decided on a loadout and inventory, the battles themselves get boring FAST.  -Maneuvering, either with your character or with your spacecraft feels cumbersome and restrictive, even with all the myriad ways of customizing your controls. The AI doesn't do much better though (and your own AI team mates and NPC characters have a nasty tendency to get stuck in corners or in tight hallways causing many of the game's areas to have uncharacteristically (uncharacteristic for the world of Star Trek even) large hallways and open spaces.  -You probably have to really love star trek to want to play this game. At least this is the way it was with me. The game world is a messy hodge-podge of every star trek episode and movie ever made and while this can be great for people looking for nostalgia and gives you a huge variety of enemies to fight the world can seem like a real chaotic mess unless you are fairly familiar with most star trek episodes and movies which have ever come out. The game tries to introduce you to things though but this game requires a LOT of reading text boxes to find out what's going on, almost from one minute to the next.  --The game world attempts to control overcrowding and lag issues by having different 'instances' or sort of sub-space like parallel universes running at the same time. To actually join your friends and see them you have to figure out how to join their particular 'instance.'

Star Trek Online is a game that I not only find to be incredibly fun and engaging, but that I also respect it because of its Free to Play model. There's little here that I actually dislike about the game and, for me personally, I can only think of one minor glitch that I've encountered throughout my whole time playing.  So, where to start? Well, the ship combat system is so much fun and so well designed. If you've ever played the old Starfleet Command games you'll see that the combat system here is very familiar while also clearly standing on its own. Every ability you gain as you level has a specific use and, as you level, the combat becomes more and more challenging. You have to use your abilities at the right time and where you're strongest and where you're weakest. There's a good amount of tactics you can and have to use in the space combat, providing a fun challenge. Ground combat is okay yes, but doesn't compare to the space combat.  The UI is quick to understand and easy to modify to personal preferences. Character customization is magnificent and, for an RPer like me, I absolutely love how I can put in a background description for my character, and a formal name function, who would think to put that there? And you'd think it would stop for just your character, but no, you can customize your bridge officers with their looks, names, and fill out a background from them as well as their skills to use in combat, allowing for even more immersion into the game's world.  And then there's the Free to Play model the game uses, this makes me respect the game and their developers even more. Like all Free to Play games, there is a special freemium currency where one can use real money to get and buy special extras that non-subscribers can't get. For STO that can be ships or ship designs, extra character slots, certain races can't be played, and certain costumes/uniforms can't be gained without using this currency. However, there is a legitimate way to gain this freemium currency, called ZEN, without spending money for those who want some of those bonus goodies but won't, or can't (in my case) spend money for it. Basically there is a secondary currency in the game called Dilithium, which certain (repeatable every 20 or so hours) missions award as ore, you can refine the ore into crystals which, through the Dilithium exchance, you can sell a large amount of Dilithium for ZEN, roughly 150 per ZEN. Non-subscribed players can only refine a certain amount per day, 8'000 specifically. Per Character, before resetting the next day. Depending on what faction your characters join/side with, Starfleet or Klingons, you'll gain roughly some 3'000-4'000 dilithium ore by doing these repeatable missions, and your DOFF system can bring in some small bonus Dilithium while you're not playing (Don't worry, once you reach lvl 10 the system is usable to you and it's easy to learn and understand). So yes, with time, effort and patience, non-subscribed players can have most of the same bonuses as subscribed players can.  The fact that it is possible for non-subscribed players to get ZEN, while at a slower but not unreasonable rate, is where most of my respect for the game comes from, and the fact that, so far, it's not all in your face about how you don't have everything when you could with some cash (I'm looking at you, TOR).  In short, do I recommend this game, even to casual fans of Star Trek? Absolutely, heck I didn't even consider myself a fan of Star Trek before playing this game. Now, I'm watching DS9 and loving it, so yes, I do recommend it. At least try the game out is all I can suggest.

STO as one sentence: DO NOT PLAY UNLESS YOU REALLY LOVE STAR TREK BECAUSE YOU'll BE SO LOST IT'LL PHYSICALLY HURT.  STO as a set of percentages: - 25% decent single player campaign (of which 60% cool space combat, 30% passable ground combat, 10% dialogue) - 15% references to Star Trek TV and films - 5% references to books I doubt anyone's read - 35% grindy end-game content (of which 40% Special Task Forces, 30% ground battlezone, 20% getting stuck in another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ UNDINE RIFT DAMNIT FULL POWER TO IMPULSE, 10% New Romulus) - 5% scumming the exchange to put together your ship build - 5% grindy holiday events - 5% customising the look of your ship because it's never quite right - 5% slightly-iffy-but-erring-on-the-side-of-acceptable real-world-money transactions (NOTE: optional, yes I'm talking to you, official forums)  In summation of the summation - I always claimed not to like the 'theme park' style MMO, and STO does have shades of that, but I thought the extremely competent single-player missions make up for most of the other shortcomings. If you're only interested in that, there's probably somewhere in the region of 100-150 hours worth of decent Star Trek here that you won't have to pay a penny for.  If you want to go deeper, find a fleet. Worst case scenario - it's a place to dump all your excess resources in return for some shiny ships. Best case scenario - the above plus a group of cool people who do events and stuff. Overall - 7.5/10.

Looking for some Sci-Fi action? Ever wanted to take the center chair, uphold the finest traditions of Starfleet, fight with honor and glory in the Klingon Empire, or do you want to help the new faction of Romulans and aid their Republic? If you like RPG, action, combat, story, and MMOs, then I can safely say that Star Trek Online is the game for you.  Ever since becoming free to play in 2012, many, MANY more people have been drawn to this game. three factions to choose from, are you with the Federation? the Defense Force? or New Romulus? walk one of three potential career paths for each faction, customize your starships, your bridge officers, your character's appearance, race, features, and even your traits~  Utilize the Zen store to improve your gaming experience with top-quality items, ship refits, retrofits, unique weapons, consoles, and so forth.  With so much content, so many PvE (Player versus Enemy) queues, Fleets, the reputation system, and playing with friends, STO's one of those games you'll fondly come back to after a needed break, and nostalgialize your experience all over again.  Go on the offensive with high DPS or opt for total stealth through the Tactical wing. Bulk out your defense and longevity, and support your fellow crewmates and allied ships through the Engineer corps. or see that your team mates stay alive, and keep them in the fight, while severely hampering your enemies in the Scientific Branch.  With a starting character slot count of 3, you can walk any race and any career of your choice, and even expand if you have the Zen for it, so beam into the realm of Trek, take command of the bridge, and set course... For Adventure.

A super fun MMO that really is FREE to play. You can get all the way from 1 to 50 (max level currently) without spending a dime. Sure, there are some neat goodies you can buy (and I often do) but they aren't game breaking and you can get to max level and earn in game money just selling off parts of the ships you blow up or from mission rewards. For example, you are rewarded with a new ship each time to earn a rank (evern few levels) OR you can spend some money and buy the same ship with a different skin and an extra officer slot and a fun console (grappling hook, low damage auto turret, etc.) but the ship reward is just perfectly fine to go out and blow up bad guys with.  The community is top notch and (as would be expected) are a Star Trek lovin' bunch. Lots of great fleets to join as well as all level of RPers.  Character customization is top notch (as you would expect from Crypic) and the ability to customize the look of your crew is a big bonus. From Borg to Ferengi, hell, throw a few Pakleds on your bridge crew. Most of the major races are represented as well as a few of the lesser known ones. Or just make up your own with the character creator.  Ground combat and exploration is fun but the game really shines in space combat. You can level in PVE, PVP or let your crew do the work and send your duty officers and crew off to do assignments. It's up to you.  All in all, it's my go to MMO for when I'm 'between games' and since it's F2P I can always hop back in and pick up where I left off. It has a permanent spot on my hard drive.

If you are a Star Trek fan, this game is a must. The storyline is fun and engaging (if Star Trek is your thing) and as a whole this game is probably the best Star Trek execution in a game ever. If you aren't into MMORPGs, you can treat it as a nice, long singleplayer campaign with the possiblity for coop-play. If you're not fuzzed about Star Trek either way, then this is just another MMORPG. Like WoW and others like it, there is a relatively long leveling process and then an endgame grind that can take as long as you want it to with regular updates to the content. Like WoW and other MMORPGs, the endgame dungeons become 1 part skill and 2 parts finding the glitches (aka weaknesses) of that particular boss (yes, I don't like that kind of gameplay). Also, this game has added some endgame content that would have to be considered pay-to-win if you are playing competitively (like essentially all the F2P MMORPGs do). If you really dislike Star Trek (or sci-fi in general), you probably won't like this game either
