Wow, what an amazing game.  My first impression of this game was not good. The graphics were terrible and glitchy and everything didn't seem polished. I played for a few hours anyways just to give it a shot. Then I realized my graphic settings were not setup properly. Once I corrected a few settings, the game looks amazing. I continued playing and finished a few missions and realized the gameplay is better than any paid MMO I've tried to date. The missions and gameplay remind me of the first SWTOR and Mass Effect. Once you learn that you can press 'B' on the ground missions to actually get into the fighting, it's really immersive. The space fighting is also intense with the different team skills playing their individual roles. And its the first MMO where the missions aren't based on collecting 10 flowers, or killing 20 bears. It's actually story driven and similar to the star trek movies and shows.  Overall, the game is great. It's free, so why not give it a try. Its still has flaws, but take the time to setup the graphics properly and work through a few missions. I think you'll be surprised.

This game is great.  The game is free to play, and from what I've seen, the free version is good enough. I wouldn't know, because the beta had me hooked, and I signed up for a lifetime subscription before they went free to play. Even though they went free to play, I don't regret the lifetime subscription. This game is great.  There are two things that are awesome about this game: 1. Episodes. They have a bunch of quests in the game that are built together into an episode. Which mimics what you might see on the show. Usually they have some space battles, and some ground battles, and they always have great stories. The rest of the quests in the game are meh. Holidays can be fun, but I've never put tons of hours into those. Story missions bring me back. Not much else. 2. Space Combat. I love the style of space combat. Having to worry about shield strength, and positioning is a lot of fun. And because of the game's difficulty system, you can make it easy or difficult. Great thinking.  Things that are great, but not awesome: 1. Duty Rosters. It's basically giving everyone on your crew something to do. It's kinda like a minigame, and it can be tons of fun, but it doesn't have the epic feel of the Episodes or the Space combat, because it's just a quest.  Things that are not great: 1. Ground combat. It's not amazing, but it's fine. 2. Daily / repeatable quests. Boring. I thought I would really like the exploration system, but it wasn't really exploration the way I wanted it. It was grinding. Some of the storyline missions are repeatable, and that's not what I'm talking about, I'm talking about the quests that just keep coming back, like patrol missions and such. Meh. I just skip them. I can never even bring myself to clean more than one out of my mission log in any given month, so the few I've collected mostly just sit there.  Things I've got mixed feelings on: 1. 'Guild' system. I'm in a guild, but I don't really feel like I do much with it. There's fun things to do with a group, but I can do most of the stuff I want to do without a group. I'd like to do some of the content that's multiplayer exclusive, but I want an easier way to do it. 2. Reputation. The Reputation systems are kinda interesting but pretty grindy. I haven't committed months of my life to this game, but there's stuff to do if this is where you want to spend your time.

Of all the MMOs I've played (and there have been several), Star Trek Online is the only one I've stuck with. If you're like me and you like being able to solo from time to time, this is your game. While some missions are restricted to Fleets (the STO equivalent of guilds) or groups, the main storyline of each faction (Federation, Romulan, or Klingon) can be done entirely solo.  The characters you create are  completely  customizable, right down to the sizes of their hands and lengths of their fingers, if you're a sucker for extremely tiny details. If you're not that into the minutiae, there are a number of presets as well as a button to randomize your character's physical appearance. Uniform parts and pieces may be mixed and matched as well as recolored to your taste, and your character may have multiple uniforms that you can switch between as you choose. You can also fully customize the uniforms and appearances of your bridge officers.  Space combat was tricky for me to get used to at first, but once you learn how everything works, it's really quite fun. Each of your bridge officers has special abilities that can be applied in combat, and different ships have different abilities as well. You can fully upgrade your ships with new equipment, and at every 10 levels (e.g. each promotion), you receive a new ship for free. Ground combat is (as another reviewer mentioned) a little repetitive, but the drop rewards from defeated enemies are often fairly substantial as you move into higher levels of play.  While there are options to purchase unique ships, officers and various other items using real world currency, you are at no point required to spend money to access the main features of the game, and I haven't yet felt as if the game is overwhelmingly 'pay-to-win.' So far I've been successful with what I've received directly from story progression (as of this writing my main character is level 26 out of 50 -- yes, I'm a latecomer). Whether this still holds if you participate in PvP combat or not, I don't know, but since I don't intend to do any PvP, it's not really important to me. That said, I do have a monthly subscription and I've spent a bit of money on Zen (the cash currency) because I want to support the future of the game.  Finally: if you're a Star Trek fan (myself included in this category), you will probably enjoy the occasional cameos by various characters from the series and the films. Among others, Denise Crosby appears as the voice of Sela and the alternate-timeline version of Tasha Yar from 'Yesterday's Enterprise', and Michael Dorn makes a cameo as Worf.  In short: Star Trek Online is great fun and I plan to continue playing it for some time to come.

Okay, I won't lie, this game is a lot of fun. It adds in mechanics of very popular MMORPG's to Star Trek!   It is seriously a great game! But there are a few sets of problems. The rules and game play can be extremely confusing! Sending crew members to do work, getting new ships, finding more crew members, customizing, it's all very confusing. It's annoying as to how confusing it can be. The items are also confusing when you're thinking 'which is better and how?' or when you're trying to give it to a partner you've brought to the ground with you. Abilities are also hard to use/understand.   I guess this is a positive when you think 'Oh I'll always find something new' but it wasn't enough for me. What made it for me was the SPACE BATTLES! THOSE MADE THE GAME! Seriously, you'd be flying around and then six lasers come at you while you shoot out a few torpedos and more lasers. That is what made the game for me.  You will have hours of fun (especially because it's free) with this game, so there's no harm in downloading it and trying it out.

This game devoured my life for countless hours, but may not be for everyone. For a person like me who loved Startrek and was happy to have a chance to make my own captain and have my own adventures, it was fantastic. If you enjoy getting into a game, roleplaying the character (even if it's just in your own head.) and don't mind the fact that the game is in general fairly easy it will be worth the low, low admission price of exactly zero dollars.   I would recommend perhaps picking up a friend to play with, and allowing yourselves just pretend you're the Captain's in your team chat. Get in character, have fun and don't worry about being silly. No one has the right to judge you for having a bit of good natured fun.

I have been playing this game since the private Beta when Atari still owned it. This game has seen so much positive change since then, it is almost astounding. I remember when there used to be 15 ships on that you could play as on the federation side, and the only diversity was the meager hull decals selects Captains could choose from. Now, OMG! it has gotten to the point where I am seeing ships I don't know the name of, or even where in the Star Trek universe it came from! It's amazing!  The development team behind this game is churning out new content and upgrades, some good some bad, pretty consistently. It may help that the weekly(?) dev blogs outline what’s new and what’s being worked on, so it keeps you in the loop. STFs (Raids) have grown from, like 3, missions into 3 STFs per faction. O yeah, there are factions now. So you can get your reputation up with a certain race of aliens in order to be able to craft rare item sets and unique weapon and console pieces. There never used to be anything like that.  On the downside, they have taken out some content, such as Memory Alpha and huge exploration areas that used to yield special crafting materials. While this deletion serves a purpose, it outraged many long time fans. But, as I said, it served a purpose, and you will either appreciate it or or loathe it, it's up to you. Graphics have never gone down, they have remastered almost every mission that has been in the game since the beta. The missions regains replay-ability for some of us veterans, as the levels and story are now more coherent and look beautiful. Character models stay true to Authentic Star Trek cannon, as does the political and physical map. The new Star trek movies play a part in this universe as far as time line so, but it is not significant. (Spoilers) Aside from the Romulan home world being sucked into a black hole the universe still contains TNG, DS9, and Voyager characters and past events laid forward in those series, including TOS are laced within this storyline and time arc. So consistency will remain from all the old TV shows you grew up with. Which, for me, was very important. Voice actors from all those series have or will participate in lending their voices into the game, so keep an ear out for your favorite TV show character.  The free to play system is one of the few games you can truly accomplish anything without paying a dime. That is, if you don't mind a ♥♥♥♥ ton of grinding. Still, grinding the only way to truly earn something in a video game and that will remain true in any video game you don't have to pay for. If you choose to pay, you can purchase points to use in an in-game store and get anything from ships, to crafting material, extra character slots, ect... You can also purchase a lifetime membership that gives you an allowance of those points to use each month. You can also purchase this membership on a monthly time table.  Overall, I would give this game a solid 8.5, and this is coming from a lifelong Star Trek fan and video game enthusiast. While some would argue a 10 would be more fitting for a game that allows space and ground combat AND also follows very closely to the source material. I have to agree but also point out that there are still things that need to be added and slightly polished. At times, its a bit chaotic to know what the best build are for a specific armor set and ship combination, due to the sheer size of the available content in the game (google STO faction sets). I feel they need to make some of the more rarer ships more easier/cheaper to obtain, as you could spend over $100 buying in game currency to open enough lockboxes to obtain enough Lobi Crystals to buy a special ship from a certain Ferengi vendor. It's insane when you think of how many steps, time and money that go into purchasing a ship, even when compared to EVE online's mining and refining process.  Hope this help any prospective player/Captain!

I would have ignored this title when it was first released 2010, but Star Trek Online has shown its critics that any game can become better over time.  Star Trek Online has succeeded in frustrating gamers who expect an easy voyage with a huge war chest when careful allocation of resources and investments could make even a non paying customer a force to be reckon with. Its open non-restrictive skills and trait system provides gamers with a wide varity of playstyles to adapt with the frequent changes within the game. This is a great improvement compared to the old system where players have to live with the choices they made.  Lock Boxes is an interesting venture on Cryptic part. On the surface, it benefits players willing to gamble some real cash into the game. Well, they need money to run the game right?  However, assets obtained from Lock Boxes, unlike premium items bought by Zen, can be sold on the exchange. Whether you're a paying customer or a freeloader like me, it boils down to how well you could earn your way through STO. Nonetheless, STO is a PVE game where you just need to be good enough to survive and succeed in missions. Not an 'Alpha Predator' out there to hunt down other players.  This game works well as a Sci Fi MMORPG regardless of whatever universe it is set in.  Delta Rising Review Pending due to a huge amount of bugs.

Outstanding! One of the few MMO's in which being a Free player is just as rewarding. Nothing in the game is locked to paid players only, and playing normally provides resources which can potentially be traded to premium players for all in-game currencies. This is one MMO you'll still be playing years later, as all your time investment is worth something.  The story of the 'original universe' continues. New 'episodes' come out all the time, voiced by the TV show actors.

Some games have no right to be as enjoyable as they are. This is absolutely one of those games. For an MMO, there is virtually no grind, for a F2P game there are virtually no strings to trip you up into purchases, my only broad qualm about the game would be that for Star Trek there's enough shooting going on to make the Dominion War look like a border skirmish. And lets face it, it would be pretty boring without.  You'll be hard pressed to find a game that better portrays the nuances of 3-D space-fleet combat, especially for the price label, outfitting your ship which can be anything from a shuttle Kirk would ride in to the intimidating dreadnoughts of the Jem'Hadar flocked by wings of fighters to suit your style whether it's making broadside passes or hit and runs there's weapons for everything. The game also boasts an exceptoional level of customization, want to be a midget clone of Picard in neon pink swim shorts? Go for it. Want to honour your favourite OCDNs by making it one of your bridge bunnies? Can't guarantee 100% match but you will get damn close. Not the creative type? No worries pick your favourite Star Trek species and you've got it (barring perhaps an 8472 or Q).  Well worth a shot, even if you're not remotely a Star Trek fan. It's free to play, what do you have to lose?

If you liked the adventorous nature of Star Trek series... This game is definately for you.  If you dont know a crap or just a slight bit about Star Trek online but you enjoy a game where you can either be laidback, be roleplaying or be a hardcore dps beast but still do fine and enjoy having somewhat scientifically accurate space-exploration-pew pew and ground-pew-pew adventure.. like me.. This game is definately for you.  In this game you command; -A starship that you equip every piece of gun or consoles yourself -Your own character And you can; -Explore space & planets -Do get involved in a neat story-quest line, which is extremely nice -Command your crew -Be respected as a captain from all around, be a responsible person (or not) -Pilot smaller craft -Have a senior staff which never leaves your side and which you can fully customize them, from skills to outfits.. or their faces, races.. guns.. or anything. -Customize yourself and your clothes and armor with many many many choices and combinations -Craft weapons, armor, shields and techs and stuff for either space or ground use, or trade! -Craft Consoles, armors, warp engines, deflector dishes, torpedos for your ship, cannons, beams and stuff for yo' pimpvagon ship. -Send your crew to carry missions which may result in many possible outcomes, including injuries and so. -Send your specificly expertised researcher crew to do research. (and obtain those crew first) -Do some small scale mining to fuel up your wallet! (can be converted into ZEN, pay-to-get currency!) -Go to dance parties with yo' custom outfits -Customize your ships interiors and exteriors! Or just hang around your quarters chilling.. or order your chef to make you some food! -Chill and watch the sparks of a new massive ESD (or other) chat channel argument coming up! You would like the community, its pretty mature! -Play absolutely without any cost of money if you wanna, dont really ever feel P2W happening. Heck, the versatility in the game allows you to NOT try to copy just a single 'the best' build. You can have a ship wrapped in toilet paper as armor but still be the one that keeps everyone going!  The atmosphere of commandering a ship in a real amazing storyline and sandbox space exploration really got me to this game. I truly reccomend you give it a try.

I have played the game since its release back in 2010. Played for a lot longer then it says on steam. If you are a fan of star trek I would greatly suggest playing, more so now with the Agents of Yesterday update that puts you in the 23rd century to start with.  Things I greatly enjoy is this game does not punish you for how often you play, casual players can earn everything more regular players can just at a slower pace. People do say the game is pay to win but its really more to pay for convenience. You can use the ingame currency Dilithium to trade for the premium currency Zen. If you only trade your daily 8k dilithum per character for zen it will take a while to earn enough for a Zen store ship. But you can set buy/sell orders with the zen exchange and earn enough much faster.   The large updates they come out with now and again, breathe quite a bit of life into the game after the older content gets stale. There is certainly some grinding as with most mmo endgame content. But it feels more like a timegate that prevents you from rushing through the content and ships too quickly. But I will say the reputation system for the endgame does need a rework.   They are also working on what appears to be a graphical overhaul and are slowly rolling out features for it when they can. Thouse with better GPU's I would suggest going though the options and turning quite a bit up and set to use more ram. I would greatly like to see an autodetection feature ingame, that would set certain things for newer players.   On a score of 10, I would rate this game atleast a 7.5 maybe an 8 of ten. There is grinding that some does need to be reworked, but compared to other mmo's I have played in the past none of them have kept my attention for so long save for tabula rasa and Earth and Beyond.   I greatly look forward to where this game will head now that Abram's contract with star trek is over and new content is open to the company and not limited by the monopoly JJ abrams had.

A lot of the story pieces are fully voiced and offer interesting and differant objectives. I love RPGs as much as the next guy and believe me iv spent my fair share of time working for my stats/lvls but.... It just feals like its there to hold you back and make the game longer. It does not add value. Now dont mistake that for me saying there abilitys/RPG menus are crap they have a purpose. l dont think missions should be lvl locked and l dont think stats should buff per lvl. You know warframe style. Level up based of players choices more than basic stats. The games pritty responcive but its still not about skill shots. -Although its realy cool that lots of story is voiced it could realy have used more voicing. I know what that work load would be like and it doesnt hurt the game as much as it would just have made it that much better. -A lot of items, ships etc are expencive. Many requir $ money and im not realy sure if theres an alt method. Some ships can be earned without paying just by lvling till its unlocked then spending ingame currency. Theres also a $/credit trade system ingame but as far as l know its well past the overpriced point. Theres also a limit to how much trade credit(dilithium) a free user can refine a day. -Not user friendly menus. Realy messy menu system.  Finaly, although l have had no issues moving forwerd and enjoying my exp 100% free l dont realy know how much value is locked away in $ money l8er on. Gameplay is simple but fun. The ships are cool and well designed. The world is treky and enjoyable.  8/10

Honestly, I'm not a huge MMO player. But when I saw this game on Steam, I decided to check it out. I came in expecting just another MMO. But, boy, was I mistaken. This game has some of the flaws that other MMOs do, but it makes up for those flaws with a great story and several easter eggs, which are perfect for any diehard Star Trek fan. However, if you're not a Star Trek fan you'll probably just come into this game and see a somewhat cool sci-fi MMO with slightly less flaws then any other MMO.  Now I'm going to list my personal pros and cons, and then I'll give you my verdict.  Pros: Excellent story  Great Easter eggs for Star Trek fans Space combat Not A PTW MMO  Cons: Ground combat is alright You have to pay for some ships    So, overall I think this is a great game and I highly recommend it to Star Trek fans.  8/10

If are into MMORPG, Star Trek Online is surely one of the best F2P you can get. It's fun. Also you get a big campaign with episodes much like in a series, with one big arch story for every campaign. You also have 3 nations/factions to pick, and since you can make 3 characters free, you can play with all of them (sometimes different factions have distinct missions. Every faction also has their unique set of spaceships). Every 10 levels (up until lvl 40) you get a new free ship to match your level, you can customize ships and rename them. You can have a crew and up to 4 more bots in your party. Also you are able to land on planets (not in all of them), which makes the balance between space and ground combat better. Although ground combat can be a little strange and seems a little unpolished or laggy most of the time. Overall it's a nice MMO and worth the time invested if you want that type of experience.

I played this game for almost 700 hours before getting it on Steam (seriously, do not get Arc!), and saw a large amount of the game's progression. There are quite a few bad aspects, but many good ones, and this game is just too good for any ST fan not to play.  Pros:  Amazing storyline, doesn't matter if you liked TOS, TNG, VOY, there is something for everyone. (They even got most of the Voyager cast, Worf, Tasha Yarr, etc. to voice.) Space combat is fun, although quite spacebar-spammy. Ground combat is being worked on constantly, and a few people like it better than space. The devs, although not very fast at fixing bugs, add a lot of new ships, story missions, and updates that after 5 years has not shown signs of slowing down. Music is absolutely amazing, although it doesn't sound like anything at all out of Star Trek. Stupidly detailed character creation. 3 factions, choose to play as Federation, Klingon, or Romulan.  Cons:  Quite P2W in many situations. The ships you get after leveling up are not that great, but you can always snag a ship or two from a giveaway, some of which are quite good. Learning curve. Do your research before joining a PVE queue, or building a good setup. Grindy, but getting better every day. The only truely awful grinds are Reputation and R&D, which each have a daily that must be completed about a thousand times. Buggier than the Amazon jungle. You will need a fairly decent computer to run this game.  Overall, a must-get for any Star Trek fan.

I wish there was a middle-of-the-road option where I could recommend this game under certain circumstances. But since there isn't one, I feel like the most honest thing I can do is not to.  I have a few hundred hours invested in this game, which I started to play in 2014. Since then I've gotten my main character to 60, and created a few alts that are on their way there as well. I've pretty much exhausted all there is to do in my main, and finally feel like I can do this justice with a review.  So is this a bad game? I am inclined to say no. However, there are many negative things that will hold the experience back for you. The thing is that, mostly, they are not enough to stop you from playing once you've tried it and if you've liked it for what it is. But after a while, dissapointment might start to catch up with you nonetheless.  STO is a bittersweet experience. I feel that most of the time, for every three good things this game has, there is also one bad thing to go along.  Pros:  -The episodes are really good. This game has an interesting story that kept me going from beginning to end to see what happens. -Space combat is not the most deep out there, but its satisfying and fun. Yes it's brainless and a spacebar smasher, but enjoyable. -It feels like a true Star Trek experience, despite some questionable things lore-wise. -Missions are repetitive, yeah, but more often than not many of them can be quite creative and entertaining. -There is a lot of room for roleplaying if you're into that sort of thing. -A good amount of content that will keep you busy for a few hundred hours. -The foundry allows for some welcome creativity and what I consider the most meaningful player run aspect of the game. It helps keep things fresh and going when you are out of episodes from the game's main storyline. -Getting in-game currency is not as painful as in other games, and the Exchange (a.k.a auction house) is great for fattening up your wallet. -There is a sizeable amount of voice acting (many of it from actors of the actual Trek shows) to help immersion. -You can customize your character appearance anytime you want, and as many times as you'd like. -The fleet (a.k.a guilds) system is good and has a lot of things going for it, from your own fleet starbase to many other cool things you can add and customize in it. -There is a decent amount of fan service and the tie ins between the tv shows and the game can be clever from time to time. -There are nice events that let you have neat things, as well as giveaways for the same purpose. -The game is regularly updated with content.  Cons:  -The game is designed to extract money from you. What I hate is that half of how it's done seems appropiate to me. The game seduces you to buy uniforms and packs from your favorite shows. If the milking would have stopped there, It would have been fine. But nope, the game asks you to pay up for the best ships of the game, or grind dilithium for around 2 months just to get one of the tier 6 ships (currently the best ones). And then theres the whole 'pay here for xp boosts, pay here to unlock more inventory slots, more character slots, and this and that, and etc.' which isn't as annoying as how it was on SWTOR, but still pretty out there. -Ground combat is terrible. At first, I accepted it for what it was, but after hundreds of hours invested here I have come to grips with reality and had to admit the truth: it is just horrible. Shallow, thin, counterintuitive, buggy, and just an overall mess. The AI of your companions gets the job done, but it is barebones basic. And enemy AI is just laughable. Patrols can be so bugged up, their walk will jitter and flicker around like a bad LSD trip. -The game feels like a singleplayer game that was slapped the MMO label because of some online components. There isn't really any need to group for questing and exploring, and end-game content is sort of shallow to even bother and fully experience it, so that pretty much erases any meaningful purpose to grouping. -Fleet actions (a.k.a. dungeons) are ok when they are space based but horrible when ground based. And even in space they can be boring, tedious and repetitive: fight waves of guys, protect some AI ships, and a small twist here and there depending on the particular one you're doing. There are different difficulties in which you can complete these, but considering you pretty much blow through everything with standard solo gear, the need to come together to get the best pieces seems like an aftertought. Don't expect endgame organized raiding here. -The community is just dreadful. The chat on Earth Space Dock really brings out the worst in humanity. I've actually created a special tab in the chat window that filters it out for whenever I visit. Players are not helpful, and every channel feels full of slander and insufferable banter. In groups, it's the norm to roll need on everything, even if you dont really need the gear at all. -This game is not noob friendly. The UI design is not entirely convoluted, but it can take a while to figure out. The map is a mess that will make your head spin the first time around. It is a labyrinthine disaster that will not be kind to a new player at all. Hell, I'm 60 and I still get confused looking at it. -The exploration factor is virtually unexistant, except for some random missions you can pickup when flying near some planets. -There is a lot of grinding, particularly with reputation, dilithium, stuff for the fleet, credits and many other currencies. -Bugs. Bugs, bugs, bugs, bugs. Little bugs, medium bugs, large bugs, game breaking bugs. Bugs everywhere. Sometimes they get patched. Sometimes they don't. Developers are not as terrible as people often say, but they sure slack when it comes to patching for fixing errors. Not to add content, though; they can profit from that.  And despite having much more negative things to say about the game than positive and overall not recommending it, I feel obligated to answer the following question: is there any circumstance in which you would recommend the game? Surprisingly, yes.  If you are a hardcore fan of Star Trek and videogames, and you are willing to depart from some money then this is for you. Or perhaps if you are one of those fellows that do not mind to grind for months. If you like roleplaying, this game can be hours of fun as well if you find the right fleet.  If you're looking for a deep MMO with complex mechanics, don't bother downloading this. If you're not willing to open up the ol' wallet or grind your way through all the stuff you need, then keep browsing for something else as well.  What keeps this game alive and running with faithful players that follow it, is that despite all the bad, it is fun. A lot of fun actually. Many of us stick around waiting for a miracle that might never come: for Cryptic to revamp the areas that need it, and to patch the game so it can be rid of the problems it has. Perhaps a bigger developing team, and a more humane cash shop.

I've been a fan of Star Trek for a really long time. I've been to conventions, I've seen every show and movie multiple times, I've played damn near every Star Trek video game out there, and I was even at the Vegas Star Trek Convention when this game was originally announced (back when it was still being developed by Perpetual Entertainment). If Star Trek Online was going to appeal to anybody, I think it's fair to say that I would be at the front of the line.   And for a long while after Cryptic released the game, it did. Star Trek Online started off as a very decent piece of fan service to the core series. No, the stories were never the same level of quality that was seen in the TV series, but it didn't have to be. The game succesfully hit all the right buttons to be a succesful Star Trek MMO, and Cryptic legitimately seemed like they wanted to keep improving the product they had released.   Then came free to play. I have nothing against free to play as a general concept, but so many games handle it incorrectly in an attempt to increase revenue. That didn't happen immediately for STO, but after Cryptic Studios was purchased by Perfect World Entertainment, it sure didn't take long. Perfect World is very well known for churning out game after game with obnoxious freemium systems, so I suppose it shouldn't be to surprising that they did the same with STO. And that's exactly what happened.  All In all, there's still a part of STO that's good, but it's covered in so much money grabbing BS I just cant' recommend the game to anyone anymore. I would love to be able to revisit the game I played for 1000+ hours (I played on the standalone client before switching to the Steam client), but it's just not there anymore.   TLDR: Used to be a fantastic game, but it's been bogged down by to much freemium BS.

As Cryptic Studios released the game 2nd Februar 2010 they had an idea of how to make a good Star Trek Game. I played in Alpha and Beta and ordered several copies preorder to gain a lot of ingame stuff that was different on every copy of the game. They did not make it perfect at start, it had its flaws, but hey were working on it to make it better over time. I really enjoyed playing the game. You had exploring missions. Yes at some point they repeated themselves, but that is how close you can get in a game to a Star Trek feeling. The ingame store had updates from now and then and I bought some stuff, like the Defiant Retrofit (Now T5). You could speculate how a game that demands monthly money to play it can have an ingame store that requires money again, but it was another time and technically you could unlock almost anything by playing. The design was attracting a casual playing older/wealthy player base anyway. Prices were not too high and any unlocks were always account wide forever.  This all changed as Arc Games purchased Cryptic Studios and everything went downhill. The chinese company turned the game really quick into a typical chinese pay to win game. With the release of the T6 Ships around 80% of players left, for obvious reason not being willing to pay real money for them. Only other way to get these ships was brainless grinding and playing every day. Didnt take long for the famous chinese shop in shop system appeared in which you could buy stuff that only was unlocked on one character for the double price. Yes I actually calculated everything. Ofcouse you can grind everything out, but getting a T6 ship from the Zen Store without using money will take you around 150 days with one character, depending on the dilithium exchange prices and you having enough unrefined dilithium. Anyway we went enough on the pay to win part now, lets get to the gameplay. Well every patch breaks more stuff than they can fix. This is not Cryptics fault. They actually work hard I think, they just dont get any money to repair and improve stuff in the necessary amount. Arc Games is sucking everything out. The warp out animation is broken for months. An animation Cryptic originally changed 3 times at release till it satisfied them. But look here, shiny, shiny new ships. Give us your money is Arc Games answer to that. There are several issues in the game right now. Game breaking graphic bugs and never ending glitches can be expected while you play. Be sure the server disconnects you around 30s per map you are moving. Now lets get to the part if you really have to pay money. Yes and no. Technically you can play with your free ship, but the enemies are getting stronger and stronger and standing a chance with a T5 ship against the Vaadwaur proves challenging, against Na'kuhl it is suiciding through the missions. If this still didnt convince let me you tell you that, besides having bought multiple keys for ingame items at release, I am a Lifetime Subscriber. We get free Zen every month, only reason why I still play btw. As I went back into the game after a break I had the problem I couldnt claim the T5 I bought some time ago on any other character. Wait there is a player support that I asked immediatly to get a message some days later, I just need to dismiss it on the character I own it and reclaim it there. Ofcourse I trusted the support and dissmissed the ship. Jokes on me, I couldnt reclaim it. Wrote another ticket explaining it, showing proof of the purchase. Guess what. They didnt care and didnt want to give me the ship I already paid for. I was supposed to buy it again.  Conclusion: You can play the game, some of the original good content is still there. I recommend you to make a character and just play the story once. After that stop playing. Dont waste money on it. The game is close to being dead anyway. Not later than they release T7 even the hardcore fans will leave. Really sad what lifeless, souless husk this game has become. It had great potencial and it still has. I never expected it to be like the Series. Maybe one day a better company will buy Arc Games and make the game good again.

First things first, don't let my play time fool you. I've been a player of Star Trek Online for about 5 years now and I gotta say; it's not getting any better. That said, let's start out with the good...  (TLDR At Bottom)  You can't talk about a Star Trek game without talking about immersion. This game does draw you in and make you feel like you're a part of the 24th century universe that began with Christopher Pike and continued for decades after. You feel like you’re a part of an ever growing galaxy, doing missions to better the life of those around you. That said, it’s only good immersion for one pass through. Starting a second character on the same faction finds you instantly bored and upset with having to perform the same exact story over again. Thankfully there is more than one race, which means more than one story. If you want to stay the same race though, just take a different route (Assault/Science/Engineering) you’ll find yourself performing the same story over and over again. In addition, the additional content that is added after the 3 main storylines is pretty much identical no matter what race you are. Thus, you only get one playthrough of the additional content before you're repeating it with your other races. Anyway, back to the good stuff…  Sound and graphics are well done in this game. Arguably the best Star Trek experience yet. Game play adds to that experience as well. Large ships, while having more firepower and armor, actually feel bulky and slow while smaller ships are much faster and more maneuverable. You have to customize your equipment/ship to the style you play or you’ll quickly find yourself in a lot of trouble when an enemy race locks its weapons on you. There are also a HUGE array of ships you can use, of all classes and sizes, bringing a high level of variety, sort of...  Now let’s get to the bad. This game is distributed by Perfect World. That means the game is free, but not really. The game has been slowly converted from a very balanced system to what exists today, a heavy “pay to win” system. The best ships are only really available on the marketplace and every new ship has a higher price than the last newest ship. Now, I’m not going to say I haven’t purchased my share of ships, because I have. But it gets extremely frustrating when a ship you paid good money for is suddenly made inferior by the next ship released, with that ship then being made inferior by the next, and so on, and so on, and so on. This has quickly become the biggest money grab in the history of MMO’s.  Today, if you want the latest collection of “Tier 6” starships (9 in total) you’ll have to fork out 12000 Zen (the store currency) for the bundle, which equals around $130 of real cash. Believe it or not, that’s actually a deal! Buying just the tripple bundle for a specific race costs 6000 Zen ($70, roughly). Buying each ship individually for 3000 Zen would be an astronomical $315! For virtual ships in a game where said ship will probably be inferior in less than a couple months, that’s a lot.  In all honesty, the pay-to-win scheme has literally destroyed this game. On top of all the crap available in the market, which includes inventory expansions, expanded ship storage, upgrades, clothing, bridge layouts, shuttles, and so on, you start to hate looting ships/people because of all the drop boxes you’ll collect. Of course, the drop boxes are locked and require you to purchase keys (from the market) to unlock them. I remember, at one time, having my inventory filled with nothing but drop boxes. Like an idiot I paid for about 30 keys (can't remember the cost, but it wasn't cheap) and got what I expected. The boxes either had absolute junk or items that would become useless within a very short time. There was always a very rare chance of getting a starship in a drop box, but I never did. That said, I've heard of people spending hundreds of dollars on keys just to get those rare ships. (Maybe Perfect World isn't stupid, because people are) After my 30 keys were used I started dumping the drop boxes in the garbage, as selling them on the auction is totally useless. Trust me, if you go to the auction and type in the name of any drop box you’ll have no less than 50 pages of already existing auctions at stupid low prices.  Some players might argue that you can trade in-game dilithium for Zen, and it’s true. That said, all this has done is pushed the cost of the items in the marketplace higher. In addition, you can only convert so much dilithium every day, and the exchange doesn’t guarantee how much your dilithium is actually worth. Honestly, it’s worse than gold farming in other MMO’s. Not worth the time or effort you’ll have to put into it.  TLDR :   So, do I recommend this game? Absolutely not. The pay-to-win scheme has pretty much destroyed this game and the massive amount of drop boxes you’ll end up looting will annoy the hell out of you. It’s got a fairly good story, which continues to expand, but the game just feels like a Ferengi designed it. So no, I don’t recommend it. Why then is my play time is as high as it is? Not really because I enjoy the game. I was one of the saps who got suckered early into sinking money into this P2W pit of decay, before we saw it for what it was, and I wanna be sure I get my money’s worth before the final nail goes in the coffin... That's why.
Their customer service always has and always will be a disaster, never expect anything from them

This game has a lot of charm for people that are deeply into retrogaming. The engine is fifteen years old and it shows. The visuals are primitive and great fun for the Playstation 2 enthusiast crowd. However, because the game is built on Cryptic's ancient proprietary engine, the game suffers tremendously.  The early (first two weeks or so) of play, this game is very entertaining. It may be prehistoric, but the pew pew is mildly entertaining. The earlier storylines are pretty good, but many have been revamped recently, and the revamps are utterly awful. The dialogue reads like it was written by a middle school student that watched too much scoobie doo growing up.  After the leveling ends, however, you are presented with the reality of the game. Since being bought out by Perfect World Entertainment, Cryptic has lost most of the rights to direct the development of their games. As a result, Star Trek Online and other Cryptic IPs like Neverwinter have recently begun losing players at a dramatic rate. The honeymoon after going FTP has reached it's inevitable conclusion with this game as Perfect World Entertainment has turned this game into a thinly veiled scam and gambling interface that utterly diminishes the intellectual property and is pretty offensive. There is a common excuse used by Cryptic apologists that 'well, all FTP games are like that these days'. Hogwash. That's no excuse.  Because Perfect World has so drastically reduced Cryptic's resources to develop the game, there has been little to no real content introduced since early last year. Ever quarter or so, Cryptic is able to scrounge together a 'featured episode' that evidently has never been edited or run through any kind of quality assurance, and call that 'content'. At the same time, the bulk of their resources and development is spent on introducing more 'lockbox' ships. These 'lockbox ships' are quickly thrown together reskins of earlier ships and don't really introduce anything to the game. You have the privilege of paying for lockbox keys in order to open the boxes that contain them if you feel lucky, as you have less than a .005% chance of getting the ship in the lockbox. The entire game runs off of this mechanic. Where a valid and reputable game has a crafting system, Star Trek Online has a gambling system, where even if you spend the 8-12 months (yes, an entire year) maxing out a single crafting skill, you can't actually craft the gear you are trying to. Instead, you are permitted a minimal 'chance' to create the desired gear.   So in the end, Star Trek Online is a good game to play for a few weeks. As the lead developer has stated the game isn't really interested in retaining players. They rely completely on gamer churn. There is no endgame content, there is no meaningful progression, there is no reason to invest a single dime in or continue playing past the level cap. Everything after that point is a sad scam designed to get you to throw out those dollars. And we're not talking three or four dollars here. For the ships gated by Perfect World Entertainment's Zen (ingame currency) store, you are expected to shell out between 25 and 120 for what you're after. 120 dollars for a ship in this prehistoric engine on a game that is just a thin veneer for a gambling simulator.   I would have recommended this game to people about two years ago. But now, as the population is disappearing and the ingame community is dwindling to nothing, as well as the development team holding a very public scorn for the remaining players, I would have to say 'save yourself the heartache'. Watching what Perfect World Entertainment has done to the Star Trek intellectual property will break your heart if you're a Star Trek fan. According to rumor there is another Star Trek MMO in the works. Wait for that one. This one isn't worth your time.

(While the review shows ive only played .8 hours of this game through steam i own a hard copy of the game i use to install so its not listed on steam. And i have played since closed beta.)  Overall quality of this game is bad. Ive been with this game since its beta and it was shipped unfinished to meet a contract deadline, they (the devs) admited this. Major problems from the beta are still present in the game now years later. devs barely update the game at all and when they do it normaly breaks it worse for a few months then it goes back to what it was before with like one spelling error fixed in one converation nobody reads anyway. The games ingame store makes the game pay to win, but all that money you are paying them they are not putting towards developing the game. Feature episodes (their version of a tv show episode) which are kinda like mini events that move forwards the timel ine of the game and cost alot of dev time can most of the time out of a 6 weeks for 6 parts series be completed in 30 minutesabout 5 min for a part some of the parts are purely walls of text to read and complete in less then 2 min.  Actual gameplay of this game is in a word repetative. Go here kill this. Go here collect this. Go here kill this to collect this. Once in a blue moon you come across an interesting quest line but most are sub par, literaly narrow hallways with the entrance on one end, 4 groups of enemies to kill and a conversation at the end. Time to max level in this game taeks about 4 to 6 weeks. Ground combat in this game is a joke it lacks anything to make it fun, boreing interiors for all but 6 missions. Space combat is not in much better shape but at least they spent time here usualy interesting looking locations but still repetative combat, enter mission - kill 4 groups - conversation - leave. This is to add 'challenge' to the game when in reality they skimped out on making the game made it kill you so you would have to eather try again and hope you DPS it to death before it can react or you grind some repetative mission to crap xp to become higher level then the guy to go back through the whole mission again to kill him and continue the sub par story that you dont even remember why your in the same exact looking base killing another dude.  While most of this game is complete crap they have at least done some interesting things to the cannon star trek story line and is at least worth playing for a month to get the story if your a star trek fan. While the early part of the game is fun and perfectly balanced problems arise in the addon and expansion content added after the Perfect World Entertainment acquisition and transition to free to play. The main issue I have with the game is the 'power creep' added to late game content and how some items and ships are clearly more powerful than any other alternatives, especially the content that free players have access to. The base game is fun, and worth exploring if you are a Star Trek fan but as you progress to end game more and more of the content will be locked behind a paywal till eventually your reach a point where you will be simply inferior to someone who has dropped cash, from a little to a lot, to improve his or her ship or crew. Through the various systems in the cash shop you can directly buy power in-game. You still have to level to use this content, but the paid cash shop content is clearly superior than anything any free player has access to, some of the rarer, more expensive shops OP to the point of imbalance.

What I liked about STO (Star Trek Online) is impossible to say. After all, I never got that far because tech support was unable to answer a simple query concerning which domains to whitelist (other than  perfectworld.com)  in order to get it running on a secure system. Let's start from the beginning: . My system is specially set up so that JavaScript, etc., runs correctly on my system only when served from a whitelisted domain. From any other domain it gets shut down - which is how I know that STO is served, in part, from unspecified domains other than  perfectworld.com  and these other domains are, consequently, not whitelisted by my security.  . What takes the cake is that, when I asked tech support for the domain names which needed to be whitelisted for the game to work, they responded by stating that the game works for “millions” of other people - which dodged the question by employing an argument by irrelevance; a form of sophistry known as a fallacy. I have to wonder if these guys even bothered to read the support ticket I lodged (given their total failure to comprehend the problem I raised) and why they couldn't simply address my question (as opposed to addressing some purely imaginary complaint).  . Now, when support techs start engaging in sophistry, it can mean that they are more interested in griefing the customers than doing their job. Moreover, this reflects very poorly on management, for obvious reasons; principally because it demonstrates the attitude that they can do no wrong and it is always someone-else's fault which, ultimately, gives rise to a fundamental disrespect for the customer base. . The bottom line is that I recommend strongly against STO and, moreover, I will not be reviewing this game again until I see some sort of evidence that key management changes have been made which facilitate policy implementation designed to ensure that customers are not systematically marginalised for the apparent crime of asking for some technical support.

Star Trek Online. This game is extremely basic, theres not much here other than the Star Trek feel, which soon goes after a few hours of playtime. I have been trying to get into this game over and over with no avail, its too boring. The ship desings and mechanics are sound, They're fun to play for a few hours every now and then, but by god dont get me started on the ground combat. I have never in my life played a game so clunky and weird, the animations are basic at best, some just seem so out of place it adds to the clunky movement and constant animation cancelling.   Annnnd thats the game folks, nothing else to mention really, Raids and such are a joke, and no one plays them, you would be in a queue for hours on end looking for 3 people. Im not sure there is even a story here, Much like the TV shows, it's individual missions with the odd big missions with a story, then its completely forgotten till you find another.   Voice acting in some parts and none existant in others, you would be best off just turning off the sound and listening to music while doing this grind of a game, actually, dont even pay attention to the missions either, because you soon get lost in what you're doing, even while paying attention.  Now, what I did like about the games was the nice little tutorial stories each faction has, it realy feels like you're a member of the Klingon Empire, the Romulan Empire and even the Federation, who of which were the most enjoyable with the whole Borg element.   But like I said, all the problems the game has, this feeling soon wears off. It is just a bad game, and the playerbase supports this, the game is pretty dead.

Now to the Cons. -Ground missions. Very repetitive and last longer than needed. -Ground Combat. Not very interesting, and PvP there is a bunch of rolling. -No exploration. If you are looking for a game that has the Pros of Star Trek, and the cons are fixed, I would recommend playing Star Wars The Old Republic.

Although I've been playing this game for far longer than what Steam is telling you, I am not sure if I should recommend this game anymore. I love Star Trek, and I do enjoy this game, but there are a lot of aspects I really do not like.  Pros of the game: - To quote Markiplier: 'SPAAAAAAAAAAACEEEE!', 'I love space!' - Any build, as long as you know how to use it, can and will be decent, though you will always lose to the wallet warriors/grindfest lovers - Some of the ships doesn't look that good, but sure as hell make up for it in being fun to fly - Scenery is nice. Very nice - Social side of the game is nice, and most people are fun to talk to - Always fun to team up with Fleet/Fleet Alliance members and do stuff - Always, ALWAYS something to do - Space PvP? Always fun to see hardened veterans beat the living ♥♥♥♥ out of wallet warriors. With a big ♥♥♥♥ing glee on their face   Cons of this game: - STO have pretty much turned into a Korean grinding MMORPG. Grinding towards the equipment you need. Even if you upgrade, you will only see a tiiiiiny fraction of an improvement over the old equipment - Too much emphasis on DPS. Way too much emphasis on DPS. Even crowd control have become almost useless - Did I mention crowd control is important, even if it doesn't have that much DPS? No? It is, but people don't have any apparently, so make sure to bring your own. Always - Federation ships, for the most part, are just sheer ugly, look bulky and doesn't look the part - Space PvP? Doesn't matter who or what you meet, you will lose regardless. Might as well be throwing rocks. At a battleship. From space - Either hit or COMPLETELY miss when experimenting with ship builds - Fully upgraded equipment? People bash you for it anyway - Not fully upgraded equipment? Lose out on the DPS race, AND have people bash you for it regardless - Did I mention the sheer amount of narrow-minded people in this game who are unable to accept ANY new builds? - Don't even get me started on the user interface, controls and camera control  Everything about this game have turned into a grindfest, to be honest. Need to fill your 8,000 Dilithium quota on one character? Grind the hell out of it! Even with the added +500 from your Fleet Dilithium Mine you're still only going to get 8,500 a day. From ONE character. Per day. And everything costs way too much. So prepare to grind that Dilithium like a fothermucker!  Have Zen? Good. It WILL be useful. Very useful. For a short while. Then you will need more. Lots more. Because everything's overpriced. Have a ship you want? Especially one of the newest ones? Save up Zen like a gold-hoarding dragon, as you will need every Zen you can get a hold of.

Had potential but too many bugs and design flaws. Most issues were related to poor mission/quest designs, so much time wasted either performing the inane boring tasks they designed specifically to absorb your time with little to no reward or creativity involved. This is truelly a money and time suck, with little effort made by the designers to provide a properly polished/finished product. With so little regard for the experiences of its customers I'm surprised that they get away with charging over $200.00 for what they call a 'lifetime' subscription, on top of charging real money for anything and everything worth getting in the game. Oh and they are sure to remind you of this fact as often as possible, from running big yellow text across your screen every time another player unlocks a new ship to regularly handing out the special chests that can only be unlocked with keys you have to purchase for $1.25 each. All ships of any worth range from $25 - $50 Each. They pretend like you can purchase everything with in game money, by trading game cash (dilithium) for it. but they limit you to a maximum of $0.20 a day, so 'IF' you play for hours each day farming dilithium and then trade in the maximum they allow of 8000 dil each day they, you can acquire a max of 20 ZEN/day/account ($1 per 100 ZEN). So just to purchase the weakest of ships is going to require repeating this for 50 days at 4-6hrs a day dilithium farming. And then after you buy your new ship there is a chance it just disappears and your left with nothing, but contempt and disdain for those greedy game designers who have wasted so much of your time/money on pretty pixels and little substance.

THE BAD: Honestly, this is not a solid MMO. The gameplay is uncreative and highly repetitive: once you've done one investigative mission that devolves from a space encounter to an away party mission and back to a space battle again, you've done them all. The various end game zones are endless rep grinds, again of highly repetitive (and boring) quests. Familiar places are not built at all to scale, making DS9 the most disappointing place in the galaxy to visit. F2P sets such a low cap on your credits that you can't compete with subbed players on the AH, although credits are worthless anyway. The costumes are buggy and frequently ugly. You can't fly your ship upside down. Need I say more?  THE GOOD: The game does have one of the strongest senses of community of any MMO I've played. The players are there because they love the franchise, which also results in some of the most hilarious barrens chat. The set up of Fleets (guilds) actually encourages player participation in cooperative group projects that help you build up your space station and unlock personal gear. I spent most of my hours playing the Duty Officer Missions, which is like a card game that lets you have multiple quests running in the background for rewards and XP. I don't think it's for everyone, but it's great to do in the background while working on real life. Leonard Nimoy voices some small parts. Oh, and it's F2P.

I wish Steam would give me a 'meh' for reviews. I will continue to play this game, so I guess that's a recommendation. But I will continue to believe it's bad in many respects. What led me to finally understand how it is bad was attempting to work with the 'The Foundry' level designer. This is a cool feature that does let players create custom missions for others to play which creates a large variety of content for players to enjoy and experience. But it's also the main problem with this game. Whereas the devs/level designers apparently have access to a more advanced version of 'The Foundry' - whatever they design with isn't much better than the Foundry.  The limits this very poorly thought out level designer puts on a level designer are enormous. The primary problem being that there's no branching to story lines AT ALL. Not a single mission lets you make a choice that will result in a variation of what happens during the quest. Many RPGs are like this - linear quests with one resolution - but even tiny variations in the progress of the mission are nearly impossible with this level designer and, the thing is, this also plays out in the missions. No branching wouldn't matter that much IF it were possible to deeply customize gameplay - but it's not. The mobs are all pretty generic in behavior and they're fought generically. The variation between classes is basically a few abilities but fighting is all done on the ground by mashing a few buttons for 'shoot phaser rifle.' But remember - there's NO BRANCHING - I mean, there's not even branching in quests as simple as 'switch this lever and go down the left hall or switch the right lever and go down the right hall and then you'll be in the main room - you can't pick both.' The only branching is in dialogue which is good and necessary, but without branching at all during the story - it feels very boring in many cases.    Anyway... kudos on the graphics but their level designing engine is ♥♥♥♥ - and the one the devs have access too isn't much better. This is fundamentally a problem with the core game engine designers who decided they'd rather not give the level designers a versitile tool which results in poor gameplay and story.   I would recommend this game to someone who really likes Star Trek and will play it just because it's Trek - but from a game design perspective - no - go play DDO which got less attention than it deserved while still kind of being a niche MMO.  Story wise, it's ok. I haven't gotten into the Federation side yet... But I started a Romulan because - well - hey - Romulan. I'm sure everyone plays Federation already. And herein is where I was first really annoyed. I'm fighting AGAINST the Romulan Star Empire for some 'pro-Democracy' split off group from the Romulan Empire (which, granted, is in chaos because Roberto Orci decided to ♥♥♥♥ everything up by destroying Romulus and Remus for his massive ego).    Anyway, being forced into a 'pro-democracy' Romulan in STO is like if you rolled a Klingon and found out you were in the pacifist faction of the Klingons which only flies freighters and works coop farms and holds peace rallies in front of the Chancellor's residence. Also I don't buy the story they're spinning with the Tal Shiar. But, then again, I guess Nemesis really started the 'absolutely screw up the Romulan storyline' habit in Star Trek so I guess Orci can't take all the blame.  Pro-democracy Romulan? Like a Klingon who cares nothing for bloodwine.   I want my old-school Romulans back - the ones who were pretty much mirrors of Cardassians but far more Nationalistic. Not the freak show they made in Enterprise and Nemesis under the incompetent hand of Berga and Berman. And the massive disaster that what Roberto Orci destroying Romulans once and for all for his stupid action movies. Where is my honorable Romulan Commander squaring off against Kirk in a battle of wits and military honor?
